_metadata.description: Central medication database for Neuro Plans - single source of truth for all medication data. Contains 936 medications harvested from 124 plans.
_metadata.safetyNotice: This database is for clinical decision support only. Always verify dosing against current prescribing information and institutional protocols.

medication.name: Display name
patientCounseling: Key counseling points

withdrawn-voluntarily-removed-from-us-ma.indication: **WITHDRAWN** — Voluntarily removed from US market April 2024 after PHOENIX trial failed to confirm benefit

ftd-als-overlap-neuroprotective.notes: **WITHDRAWN FROM MARKET (April 2024)** - Amylyx withdrew Relyvrio after the Phase III PHOENIX trial failed to demonstrate efficacy. No longer available for prescribing.

discontinued-biogen-halted-aduhelm-comme.indication: **DISCONTINUED** — Biogen halted Aduhelm commercialization January 2024; no longer available

first-line-symptomatic-treatment-for-lem.indication: First-line symptomatic treatment for LEMS; enhances presynaptic acetylcholine release by blocking potassium channels; improves strength and autonomic symptoms
first-line-symptomatic-treatment-for-lem.notes: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg per dose every 3-5 days; usual effective dose 15-20 mg TID-QID; max 80 mg/day (max 20 mg per single dose); take with food

alternative-to-4-ap-for-downbeat-nystagm.indication: Alternative to 4-AP for downbeat nystagmus; lower seizure risk than 4-AP
alternative-to-4-ap-for-downbeat-nystagm.notes: **3,4-Diaminopyridine 10 mg PO TID, titrate to max 20 mg TID (80 mg/day)**; [Kalla et al. (2007)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17664175/)

contraindications: Seizure disorder (lower risk than 4-AP but still present)
concurrent use of drugs that lower seizure threshold

ongoing: ECG at baseline and after dose changes

alternative-formulation-of-amifampridine.indication: Alternative formulation of amifampridine for LEMS; enhances presynaptic acetylcholine release by blocking potassium channels; improves strength and autonomic symptoms
alternative-formulation-of-amifampridine.notes: Start 5 mg TID; increase by 5 mg per dose every 3-5 days; usual effective dose 15-20 mg TID-QID; max 80 mg/day (max 20 mg per single dose); take with food

contraindications: concurrent use of drugs that lower seizure threshold

ongoing: ECG at baseline and after dose changes

episodic-ataxia-type-2-downbeat-nystagmu.indication: Episodic ataxia type 2; downbeat nystagmus; cerebellar gait ataxia; improves Purkinje cell function
episodic-ataxia-type-2-downbeat-nystagmu.notes: Start 5 mg BID; may increase to 10 mg BID; 12 hours apart; max 20 mg/day

first-line-for-symptomatic-downbeat-nyst.indication: First-line for symptomatic downbeat nystagmus; potassium channel blocker that improves Purkinje cell function
first-line-for-symptomatic-downbeat-nyst.notes: **4-Aminopyridine 5 mg PO BID (compounded)** or **Dalfampridine (Ampyra) 10 mg PO BID** (extended-release); [Strupp et al. (2003)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12874393/); [Claassen et al. (2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23813743/)

upbeat-nystagmus-less-evidence-than-for-.indication: Upbeat nystagmus (less evidence than for downbeat, but reasonable trial); improves oculomotor function
upbeat-nystagmus-less-evidence-than-for-.notes: **4-AP 5 mg PO BID**; trial for 2-4 weeks to assess benefit; [Glasauer et al. (2005)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15716550/)

second-line-for-pan-if-baclofen-not-tole.indication: Second-line for PAN if baclofen not tolerated or insufficient
second-line-for-pan-if-baclofen-not-tole.notes: **4-AP 5 mg PO BID**; may combine with baclofen; [Strupp et al. (2003)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12874393/)

gaze-evoked-nystagmus-from-cerebellar-pa.indication: Gaze-evoked nystagmus from cerebellar pathology (not drug-induced); improves gaze-holding function
gaze-evoked-nystagmus-from-cerebellar-pa.notes: **4-AP 5 mg PO BID**; helps with cerebellar integrator dysfunction

potassium-channel-blocker-to-enhance-neu.indication: Potassium channel blocker to enhance neuromuscular transmission; off-label, limited evidence; may improve strength in recovery phase

contraindications: cardiac arrhythmia (QT prolongation at supratherapeutic doses)
cardiac arrhythmia (prolongs QT at supratherapeutic doses)
concurrent use of other forms of 4-AP

ongoing: renal function at baseline and periodically

nrti-with-high-cpe-score-cpe-3-use-in-cn.indication: NRTI with high CPE score (CPE 3); use in CNS-optimized regimens
nrti-with-high-cpe-score-cpe-3-use-in-cn.notes: 600 mg PO daily or 300 mg BID

contraindications: **HLA-B*5701 positive** (fatal hypersensitivity reaction -- must test before prescribing)

alternative-to-onabotulinum-different-po.notes: Start 500 units divided among affected muscles; max 1000 units/session; repeat q12wk

headache-common-in-moyamoya-due-to-colla.indication: Headache (common in moyamoya due to collateral dilation); safe first-line analgesic; avoid NSAIDs (bleeding risk)
headache-common-in-moyamoya-due-to-colla.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day; AVOID NSAIDs and aspirin combinations (GI bleed)

headache-from-elevated-icp-avoid-nsaids-.indication: Headache from elevated ICP; avoid NSAIDs peri-operatively due to bleeding risk
headache-from-elevated-icp-avoid-nsaids-.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

myalgia-and-arthralgia-pain-relief.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN; max 4 g/day (2 g if hepatic impairment)

fever-target-normothermia-37-5-c-fever-w.indication: Fever (target normothermia <37.5°C; fever worsens ICH outcomes)

fever-management-in-icu-central-fever-or.indication: Fever management in ICU; central fever or status epilepticus-related hyperthermia
fever-management-in-icu-central-fever-or.notes: 1g IV/PO q6h PRN (max 4g/day); use as part of targeted temperature management (36-37C)

prevents-infusion-related-fever-and-rigo.indication: Prevents infusion-related fever and rigors during amphotericin B administration
prevents-infusion-related-fever-and-rigo.notes: 650-1000 mg PO or IV 30-60 minutes before each amphotericin B infusion; max 4 g/day

headache-and-fever-reduction-first-line-.indication: Headache and fever reduction; first-line analgesic and antipyretic for viral meningitis
headache-and-fever-reduction-first-line-.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day; IV formulation for patients unable to take PO

first-line-if-nsaid-contraindicated-mild.indication: First-line if NSAID contraindicated; mild-moderate headache
first-line-if-nsaid-contraindicated-mild.notes: 1000 mg PO at onset; repeat q6h; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease); limit to <15 days/month

first-line-oral-analgesic-in-pregnancy-f.indication: First-line oral analgesic in pregnancy for any headache

headache-and-neck-pain-from-dissection-f.indication: Headache and neck pain from dissection; fever management (temperature >38C worsens ischemic outcomes)
headache-and-neck-pain-from-dissection-f.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN; max 4g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)

prophylaxis-and-treatment-of-jarisch-her.indication: Prophylaxis and treatment of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (fever, rigors, headache, myalgia occurring 2-8h after first penicillin dose; occurs in up to 50% of neurosyphilis patients)
prophylaxis-and-treatment-of-jarisch-her.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h for first 24-48h of treatment; premedicate before first penicillin dose

headache-from-elevated-icp-or-meningeal-.indication: Headache from elevated ICP or meningeal irritation; first-line analgesic; avoid NSAIDs with concurrent methotrexate
headache-from-elevated-icp-or-meningeal-.notes: Acetaminophen 650-1000 mg PO q6h; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment); dexamethasone often most effective for LMD headache; avoid NSAIDs if concurrent methotrexate (impairs clearance) or thrombocytopenia

pain-with-eye-movement.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h as needed for pain; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease)

headache-symptom-relief.notes: 1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 3000 mg/day

headache-in-eclampsia-preeclampsia-safe-.indication: Headache in eclampsia/preeclampsia; safe in pregnancy; first-line analgesic
headache-in-eclampsia-preeclampsia-safe-.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 3000 mg/day in pregnancy; avoid in hepatic impairment (HELLP)

headache-from-elevated-icp-or-mass-effec.indication: Headache from elevated ICP or mass effect; avoid NSAIDs peri-biopsy due to bleeding risk; avoid NSAIDs during methotrexate therapy (impairs renal MTX clearance)
headache-from-elevated-icp-or-mass-effec.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

musculoskeletal-pain-and-general-discomf.indication: Musculoskeletal pain and general discomfort from immobility
musculoskeletal-pain-and-general-discomf.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

general.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day

headache-and-pain-management-avoid-nsaid.indication: Headache and pain management; avoid NSAIDs due to bleeding and hepatic risk
headache-and-pain-management-avoid-nsaid.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 2000 mg/day in liver disease (3000 mg/day if normal liver)

mild-moderate-headache-pain-during-worku.notes: 1000 mg PO/IV once; may repeat q6h; max 3000 mg/day

headache-management-headache-is-the-most.indication: Headache management; headache is the most common symptom of PACNS (60-70%)
headache-management-headache-is-the-most.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3g/day (2g/day if hepatic impairment)

mild-moderate-post-traumatic-headache.notes: 500-1000 mg PO q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day

headache-management-avoid-nsaids-while-a.notes: 1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)

pain-management-for-fall-related-injurie.indication: Pain management for fall-related injuries; myalgia (uncommon in IBM but may occur)
pain-management-for-fall-related-injurie.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN pain; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment); IV alternative: 1000 mg IV q6h if NPO

analgesic-for-thunderclap-headache-first.indication: Analgesic for thunderclap headache — first-line because it does NOT cause vasoconstriction; avoid all triptans and ergotamines
analgesic-for-thunderclap-headache-first.notes: 1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 4000 mg/day (3000 mg/day if hepatic impairment). IV: 1000 mg IV q6h PRN if NPO

headache-management-fever-control-avoid-.indication: Headache management; fever control; avoid NSAIDs if concern for GI bleed during corticosteroid therapy
headache-management-fever-control-avoid-.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day; IV route if unable to take PO

pain-control-headache-from-steroids-or-a.indication: Pain control; headache from steroids or acute attack
pain-control-headache-from-steroids-or-a.notes: 1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease)

fever-temp-38-c-worsens-outcomes.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/PR q6h; max 4g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)

fever-prevention-and-treatment-post-ttm-.indication: Fever prevention and treatment post-TTM; target normothermia (<37.7C) for at least 72h post-ROSC
fever-prevention-and-treatment-post-ttm-.notes: 1000 mg IV q6h scheduled (not PRN); max 4g/day

headache-management-headache-is-common-i.indication: Headache management; headache is common in Susac syndrome, often severe and diffuse
headache-management-headache-is-common-i.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3g/day (2g/day if hepatic impairment)

mild-attack-nsaid-contraindicated.notes: 1000 mg PO once; max 3000 mg/day; limit to ≤14 days/month

mild-moderate-pain-adjunct-avoid-hepatot.notes: 650-1000 mg q6h; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day if liver disease)

fever-management-headache-temperature-go.indication: Fever management; headache; temperature goal <38C to reduce cerebral metabolic demand
fever-management-headache-temperature-go.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day; IV route if unable to take PO

first-line-if-nsaid-contraindicated-mild.indication: First-line if NSAID contraindicated; mild-moderate TTH
first-line-if-nsaid-contraindicated-mild.notes: 1000 mg PO at onset; may repeat q6h; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease); limit to <10 days/month

headache-from-tumor-associated-edema-or-.indication: Headache from tumor-associated edema or post-operative; avoid NSAIDs peri-operatively due to bleeding risk
headache-from-tumor-associated-edema-or-.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

pain-management-for-fall-related-injurie.indication: Pain management for fall-related injuries; myalgia; headache
pain-management-for-fall-related-injurie.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN pain; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment -- liver involvement common in DM1)

musculoskeletal-pain-headache.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h; max 4g/day (2g hepatic impairment)

fever-management-target-normothermia-37-.indication: Fever management (target normothermia <37.5 degrees C; fever worsens cerebral edema)
fever-management-target-normothermia-37-.notes: 650-1000 mg PO or IV q6h; max 4 g/day; use IV if NPO

fever-reduction-and-headache-avoid-nsaid.indication: Fever reduction and headache; avoid NSAIDs due to hepatotoxicity risk with RIPE therapy
fever-reduction-and-headache-avoid-nsaid.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 3g/day (reduced from 4g due to concurrent hepatotoxic medications)

axial-neck-pain-and-musculoskeletal-pain.indication: Axial neck pain and musculoskeletal pain; first-line analgesic
axial-neck-pain-and-musculoskeletal-pain.notes: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN pain; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day if hepatic impairment or age >65)

pain-headache-fever.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)

mild-pain-adjunct-avoid-hepatotoxicity.notes: 650-1000 mg q6h; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day if liver disease)

headache-and-pain-management-fever-reduc.indication: Headache and pain management; fever reduction; alternative if NSAIDs contraindicated
headache-and-pain-management-fever-reduc.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

post-ictal-headache.notes: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg if liver disease)

contraindications: Hepatic disease, chronic alcohol use (>3 drinks/day)
Hepatic disease, chronic alcohol use >3 drinks/day
Severe hepatic disease (caution with concurrent albendazole hepatotoxicity)
Severe hepatic impairment (HELLP with transaminases >5x ULN)
chronic alcohol use (reduce max to 2 g/day)
concurrent RIPE therapy warrants reduced max dose (3g/day)
hepatic impairment (reduce dose -- GGT/ALT often elevated in DM1)

ongoing: total daily dose from all sources
total daily dose tracking across all formulations

mild-moderate-migraine-with-aura-otc-opt.notes: 2 tablets (250/250/65 mg each) at onset; max 2 doses/24hr

contraindications: avoid if using other acetaminophen sources

alternative-if-nsaids-contraindicated-ns.indication: Alternative if NSAIDs contraindicated; NSAID allergy, renal impairment, GI bleed risk
alternative-if-nsaids-contraindicated-ns.notes: 1000 mg IV over 15 min; max 3000 mg/day from all sources

first-line-parenteral-analgesic-in-pregn.indication: First-line parenteral analgesic in pregnancy when oral not tolerated
first-line-parenteral-analgesic-in-pregn.notes: 1000 mg IV over 15 min q6h; max 3000 mg/day

first-line-pain-control-for-thunderclap-.indication: First-line pain control for thunderclap headache during evaluation; avoid masking exam
first-line-pain-control-for-thunderclap-.notes: 1000 mg IV q6h; max 4g/day. Safe first-line — does not affect coagulation or mask pupillary exam

mild-moderate-pain-adjunct-when-nsaids-c.indication: Mild-moderate pain adjunct when NSAIDs contraindicated; pregnancy-safe option

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acetaminophen IV 1000 mg IV q6h IV

mild-moderate-pain-adjunct-when-nsaids-c.notes: 1000 mg IV q6h; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day if hepatic risk)

contraindications: Severe hepatic disease (Child-Pugh C), chronic alcohol use (>3 drinks/day)

ongoing: total daily dose from all acetaminophen sources

elevated-icp-from-cvt-adjunct-to-anticoa.indication: Elevated ICP from CVT (adjunct to anticoagulation); intracranial hypertension secondary to NBD
elevated-icp-from-cvt-adjunct-to-anticoa.notes: Start 250 mg BID; increase to 500 mg BID as needed; max 2000 mg/day

pulsatile-tinnitus-due-to-iih.notes: Acetazolamide 250-500 mg PO BID, titrate up to 1g BID as tolerated; monitor electrolytes; reduces CSF production; can dramatically improve pulsatile tinnitus in IIH

iih-related-pulsatile-tinnitus.notes: Acetazolamide 250-500 mg PO BID, titrate up to 1g BID as tolerated; first-line medical therapy for IIH; weight loss is critical adjunct; reduces CSF production

adjunctive-icp-reduction-in-fungal-menin.indication: Adjunctive ICP reduction in fungal meningitis with persistent mildly elevated ICP after therapeutic LPs; reduces CSF production
adjunctive-icp-reduction-in-fungal-menin.notes: 250 mg PO BID-TID; titrate to 500 mg TID if tolerated; monitor for metabolic acidosis and paresthesias

temporizing-measure-while-awaiting-surge.indication: Temporizing measure while awaiting surgery; reduces CSF production
temporizing-measure-while-awaiting-surge.notes: Start 250 mg BID; titrate to 250 mg TID or 500 mg BID; max 2 g/day

communicating-hydrocephalus-elevated-icp.indication: Communicating hydrocephalus; elevated ICP from meningeal sarcoidosis (adjunct to steroids)
communicating-hydrocephalus-elevated-icp.notes: Start 250 mg BID; may increase to 500 mg BID; max 2000 mg/day

adjunctive-icp-reduction-mild-communicat.indication: Adjunctive ICP reduction; mild communicating hydrocephalus; headache from elevated CSF pressure when surgical CSF diversion not indicated or not yet available
adjunctive-icp-reduction-mild-communicat.notes: Start 250 mg PO BID; may increase to 250 mg TID or 500 mg BID; max 2 g/day; reduces CSF production by 50%

elevated-icp-without-indication-for-emer.indication: Elevated ICP without indication for emergent surgical intervention
elevated-icp-without-indication-for-emer.notes: Start 250 mg PO BID; titrate to 500 mg BID; max 2000 mg/day

general.notes: 500 mg BID; titrate to 2-4 g/day as tolerated; IIHTT used up to 4 g/day

episodic-ataxia-type-2-ea2-cacna1a-mutat.indication: Episodic ataxia type 2 (EA2, CACNA1A mutation); first-line preventive therapy; reduces frequency and severity of episodes
episodic-ataxia-type-2-ea2-cacna1a-mutat.notes: Start 250 mg BID; titrate to 250-500 mg BID-TID based on response; max 1000 mg/day

myotonia-refractory-to-first-line-agents.indication: Myotonia refractory to first-line agents; may improve myotonia through carbonic anhydrase inhibition; limited evidence
myotonia-refractory-to-first-line-agents.notes: Start 250 mg PO BID; may increase to 250 mg TID; max 1000 mg/day

hemiplegic-migraine-prevention-familial-.indication: Hemiplegic migraine prevention; familial hemiplegic migraine
hemiplegic-migraine-prevention-familial-.notes: Start 250 mg BID; may increase to 500 mg BID

contraindications: Sulfa allergy, severe renal/hepatic disease, hypokalemia

ongoing: Electrolytes (potassium, bicarbonate) weekly x 4 weeks, then monthly
K+, bicarb, renal function q1-3 months
[NORDIC Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension Study Group (2014)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24687293/): acetazolamide effective for IIH

general.notes: 80-120 units IM daily × 2-3 weeks; alternative to steroids
Triptans (sumatriptan 50-100 mg PO, 6 mg SQ); NSAIDs; antiemetics (ondansetron, metoclopramide); vestibular suppressants for vertigo component

herpes-prophylaxis-during-immunosuppress.indication: Herpes prophylaxis during immunosuppressive chemotherapy; rituximab increases reactivation risk
herpes-prophylaxis-during-immunosuppress.notes: Acyclovir 400 mg PO BID or valacyclovir 500 mg PO daily; continue during chemotherapy and 3-6 months after completion

general.notes: 400 mg PO 5× daily × 7-10 days; or 800 mg PO TID × 7 days

empiric-hsv-encephalitis-coverage-if-fev.indication: Empiric HSV encephalitis coverage if fever, altered mental status, temporal lobe abnormalities
empiric-hsv-encephalitis-coverage-if-fev.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (based on ideal body weight); adjust for renal function

encephalopathy-of-unknown-etiology-pendi.indication: Encephalopathy of unknown etiology pending HSV PCR

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (empiric until HSV ruled out) 10 mg/kg IV

encephalopathy-of-unknown-etiology-pendi.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h; continue until HSV PCR negative x2 (48h apart) or alternative diagnosis confirmed

general.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (infuse over 1h). Base on IDEAL body weight (IBW). Duration: minimum 14-21 days. Dose adjust for renal impairment: CrCl 25-50: 10 mg/kg q12h; CrCl 10-25: 10 mg/kg q24h; HD: 10 mg/kg after each dialysis session

critical-empiric-hsv-coverage-hsv-enceph.indication: CRITICAL: Empiric HSV coverage; HSV encephalitis is fatal if untreated; start on ALL patients with meningitis until HSV PCR returns negative and no encephalitic features present

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (empiric — until HSV excluded) (CPT 96365) 10 mg/kg IV

critical-empiric-hsv-coverage-hsv-enceph.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (based on ideal body weight); infuse over 1h; discontinue when HSV PCR negative AND no encephalitic features (confusion, focal deficits, seizures, temporal lobe MRI changes). CrCl 25-50: q12h; CrCl 10-25: q24h

targeted-therapy-for-vzv-meningitis-with.indication: Targeted therapy for VZV meningitis (with or without rash); immunocompromised patients require IV therapy; immunocompetent may be treated with oral valacyclovir if mild

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (for confirmed VZV meningitis) 10 mg/kg IV

targeted-therapy-for-vzv-meningitis-with.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (based on ideal body weight) x 10-14 days; transition to oral valacyclovir 1000 mg PO TID when clinically improving

empiric-antiviral-if-vzv-vasculopathy-no.indication: Empiric antiviral if VZV vasculopathy not yet excluded; VZV vasculopathy is a treatable and common mimic of PACNS

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (empiric, until VZV excluded) 10 mg/kg q8h IV

empiric-antiviral-if-vzv-vasculopathy-no.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h; continue until VZV PCR and VZV CSF IgG negative; infuse over 1 hour; dose adjust for renal impairment

empiric-while-awaiting-hsv-pcr-fever-enc.indication: Empiric while awaiting HSV PCR; fever + encephalopathy
empiric-while-awaiting-hsv-pcr-fever-enc.notes: 10 mg/kg IV q8h. Continue until HSV PCR confirmed negative

contraindications: True acyclovir allergy (extremely rare). Renal impairment — dose adjust, do NOT withhold

ongoing: ensure adequate hydration (1-1.5 mL/kg/h IV fluids)

refractory-nbd-alternative-to-infliximab.indication: Refractory NBD; alternative to infliximab; preferred for outpatient self-administration; refractory uveitis (FDA-approved for non-infectious uveitis)
refractory-nbd-alternative-to-infliximab.notes: 80 mg SC at week 0, then 40 mg SC every other week; increase to 40 mg weekly if inadequate response; Pre-treatment: TB testing (QuantiFERON), Hepatitis B/C screening, CBC, LFTs, chest X-ray, pregnancy test

refractory-neurosarcoidosis-alternative-.indication: Refractory neurosarcoidosis; alternative to infliximab; may be preferred for outpatient self-administration
refractory-neurosarcoidosis-alternative-.notes: 80 mg SC at week 0, then 40 mg SC every other week; may increase to 40 mg weekly or 80 mg q2wk if inadequate response

general.notes: Titration from 1-10 mg/kg IV q4 weeks; limited use

doseOptions.orderSentence: Aggressive IV hydration (rhabdomyolysis) 200-300 mL/h NS IV

rhabdomyolysis-prevention-treatment-if-c.notes: 200-300 mL/hr normal saline; target urine output >200 mL/h; consider sodium bicarbonate drip to alkalinize urine (target pH >6.5)

general.notes: **GCS ≤8:** Intubation; elevate HOB 30°; **Acute herniation:** Mannitol 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus OR hypertonic saline (23.4% NaCl 30 mL via central line over 15 min or 3% NaCl 250 mL over 30 min); maintain PaCO2 30-35 mmHg (brief hyperventilation only as bridge to definitive treatment); Emergent neurosurgery consult for decompression

ongoing: ICP management as bridge to definitive treatment (surgery/radiation)

general.notes: **GCS ≤8: Secure airway**; RSI with agents that do NOT raise ICP; preferred: etomidate 0.3 mg/kg OR propofol 1-2 mg/kg + rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg OR succinylcholine 1.5 mg/kg; AVOID ketamine in severe TBI (controversial — emerging data suggest may be safe); lidocaine 1.5 mg/kg IV 2-3 min before laryngoscopy (may blunt ICP spike — controversial benefit); avoid hypotension during RSI

ongoing: avoid hypoxia (PaO2 <60) and hypotension (SBP <90) — both worsen outcomes

general.notes: Head-tilt chin-lift, oral airway, prepare for intubation

first-line-antiparasitic-for-viable-pare.indication: **First-line antiparasitic** for viable parenchymal NCC (vesicular and colloidal stages); 1-2 viable cysts: albendazole monotherapy x 7-14 days; >2 viable cysts: combine with praziquantel; subarachnoid/racemose NCC: prolonged courses (months); take with fatty meal (increases absorption 5-fold)
first-line-antiparasitic-for-viable-pare.notes: 15 mg/kg/day PO divided BID (standard max 400 mg BID = 800 mg/day; up to 600 mg BID = 1200 mg/day for subarachnoid NCC or heavy cyst burden per ID specialist guidance); take with fatty meal; duration: 7-14 days for 1-2 parenchymal cysts; 10-14 days for >2 cysts (with praziquantel); weeks to months for subarachnoid NCC

contraindications: cysticercal encephalitis with uncontrolled edema (treat edema first)

ongoing: LFTs at baseline, day 7, day 14, then biweekly

ascites-management-hepatorenal-syndrome.notes: 1 g/kg/day (max 100 g); for large-volume paracentesis or hepatorenal syndrome

general.notes: Year 1: 12 mg IV daily × 5 days; Year 2: 12 mg IV daily × 3 days; highly active MS, REMS

contraindications: ongoing autoimmune disease other than MS

ongoing: CBC, LFTs, creatinine, urinalysis, TSH monthly × 48 months after last dose

osteoporosis-prevention-if-chronic-stero.indication: Osteoporosis prevention if chronic steroids anticipated >3 months
osteoporosis-prevention-if-chronic-stero.notes: 70 mg PO weekly on empty stomach; remain upright 30 min after

mechanisms: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine

contraindications: Acute recovery phase after myocardial infarction
precautions: Cardiac arrhythmias - ECG before starting in patients with cardiac history

Orthostatic hypotension - fall risk in elderly
AVOID in elderly (Beers Criteria - highly anticholinergic)

tiers.adjustment: Use with caution; active metabolites may accumulate

hepaticAdjustment.notes: Use lower doses; hepatically metabolized. Avoid in severe impairment.

baseline: ECG if cardiac history or age >50
Consider baseline cognitive assessment in elderly

patientCounseling: Take at bedtime due to sedation
Do not stop abruptly - taper over 2+ weeks
Avoid alcohol
May cause dry mouth - sip water, sugar-free gum
Rise slowly to prevent dizziness
Full effect may take 4-6 weeks
Avoid in very hot weather (impaired sweating)

contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust or switch formulation)

ongoing: potassium and magnesium twice daily during induction

l-monocytogenes.notes: 2 g IV q4h (+ gentamicin 5 mg/kg/day IV for synergy in first 7-10 days, if renal function allows)

Penicillin anaphylaxis (use TMP-SMX as alternative for Listeria)

general.notes: 100 mg SC daily (may increase; used in FIRES)
Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN; Dexamethasone itself is anti-emetic; Avoid metoclopramide in brain metastases patients (extrapyramidal effects)

ongoing: Nausea common with elevated ICP and with radiation therapy

general.notes: **Epidural abscess causing CES:** Empiric: Vancomycin 25-30 mg/kg IV load + ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h (or cefepime 2g IV q8h); adjust to culture/sensitivity; MRSA coverage essential; **Duration:** Typically 6-8 weeks IV antibiotics for epidural abscess; **Timing:** Start AFTER blood cultures drawn but do NOT delay if patient is deteriorating

ongoing: S. aureus (including MRSA) is most common organism in epidural abscess (60-70%)

general.notes: Start DOAC within 1-3 days for TIA (can start earlier than stroke). Preferred: Apixaban 5 mg BID (2.5 mg BID if criteria met). Alternative: Rivaroxaban 20 mg daily; Dabigatran 150 mg BID. Discontinue antiplatelet when anticoagulant started (do NOT combine long-term unless specific indication)

anticoagulation-restart.name: Anticoagulation restart (if AF or mechanical valve)

most-controversial-decision-aha-2022-may.indication: Most controversial decision. AHA 2022: may restart anticoagulation at 4-8 weeks for patients with strong indication (AF with high CHA2DS2-VASc). Avoid in CAA-related lobar ICH if possible

doseOptions.orderSentence: Anticoagulation restart (if AF or mechanical valve) N/A PO

most-controversial-decision-aha-2022-may.notes: Apixaban preferred (APACHE-AF trial: lowest ICH recurrence). Timing: 4-8 weeks; individualized risk-benefit

general.notes: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO; metoclopramide 10 mg IV (avoid in elderly — EPS); prochlorperazine 5-10 mg IV/IM

ongoing: Nausea is often the most debilitating symptom

general.notes: Metoclopramide 10 mg q8h PRN or ondansetron 4-8 mg q8h PRN
Amphotericin B 0.7-1 mg/kg/day IV + flucytosine 100 mg/kg/day x 2 weeks (induction)

all-ich-patients-bp-is-most-important-mo.indication: ALL ICH patients; BP is most important modifiable risk factor

general.notes: Target BP <130/80 mmHg. Start/restart 24-48h after TIA once stable. Agent choice per comorbidities: ACE-I/ARB first-line. Consider: Lisinopril 10-20 mg daily, Amlodipine 5-10 mg, Losartan 50-100 mg, Chlorthalidone 12.5-25 mg

restart-trial-restarting-antiplatelet-af.indication: RESTART trial: restarting antiplatelet after ICH is associated with LOWER risk of recurrent ICH; may restart at 2-4 weeks for patients with cardiovascular indication
restart-trial-restarting-antiplatelet-af.notes: Aspirin 81 mg or clopidogrel 75 mg daily

antiretroviral-therapy-for-hiv-associate.name: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) — for HIV-associated fungal meningitis

delayed-initiation-in-cryptococcal-menin.indication: DELAYED initiation in cryptococcal meningitis; starting ART too early increases IRIS risk and mortality; initiate 4-6 weeks after antifungal induction therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) — for HIV-associated fungal meningitis Per HIV specialist PO

delayed-initiation-in-cryptococcal-menin.notes: Initiate ART 4-6 WEEKS after starting antifungal therapy (NOT immediately); per COAT trial — early ART (within 1-2 weeks) increased mortality compared to delayed ART (4-6 weeks)

contraindications: Do NOT start within 2 weeks of antifungal initiation (IRIS risk)

ongoing: CD4 count and viral load q3 months
IRIS symptoms (worsening headache, fever, meningismus, new focal deficits 2-8 weeks after ART initiation)

general.notes: Valacyclovir 1000 mg TID x 7 days; evidence is WEAK; some use empirically if early presentation; thought to be HSV reactivation (like Bell's palsy)

ongoing: some clinicians still use empirically, especially if labyrinthitis with hearing loss

atrial-fibrillation-related-vascular-dem.notes: 5 mg BID (2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, Cr ≥1.5)

dissection-with-concurrent-atrial-fibril.indication: Dissection with concurrent atrial fibrillation; alternative anticoagulant if warfarin not preferred
dissection-with-concurrent-atrial-fibril.notes: 5 mg PO BID standard dose; 2.5 mg BID if >=2 of: age >=80, weight <=60 kg, Cr >=1.5; for concurrent AF or physician preference for anticoagulation strategy

alternative-doac-for-cvt-limited-data.notes: 5 mg PO BID; reduce to 2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, Cr ≥1.5

general.notes: 5 mg PO BID (2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60kg, Cr ≥1.5); start 4-14 days post-stroke for AF (timing based on infarct size). Preferred DOAC per guidelines

anticoagulation-for-stroke-with-af-prefe.indication: Anticoagulation for stroke with AF; preferred DOAC for most patients; superior to warfarin (ARISTOTLE trial)
anticoagulation-for-stroke-with-af-prefe.notes: 5 mg BID standard; reduce to 2.5 mg BID if ≥2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, creatinine ≥1.5; start 2-14 days after stroke depending on infarct size (1-3-6-12 day rule)

severe-motor-fluctuations-not-dbs-candid.indication: Severe motor fluctuations; not DBS candidate

severe-motor-fluctuations-not-dbs-candid.notes: Via subcutaneous pump; typical 3-8 mg/hr during waking hours

off-episode-in-clinic-ed-npo-patient.indication: Off episode in clinic/ED; NPO patient

second-line-atypical-antipsychotic-favor.indication: Second-line; atypical antipsychotic; favorable metabolic profile; AAN Level B

hiv-positive-patients-art-is-critical-co.notes: Preferred: bictegravir/emtricitabine/TAF (Biktarvy) 1 tablet PO daily or dolutegravir-based regimen; check for drug interactions with chemotherapy; avoid protease inhibitors (CYP interactions with chemotherapy); INSTI-based regimens preferred

drug interaction review with each chemotherapy cycle

csf-viral-escape-detectable-csf-hiv-rna-.indication: CSF viral escape (detectable CSF HIV RNA with suppressed plasma viral load); neurologic deterioration despite plasma viral suppression

keratoconjunctivitis-sicca-from-lacrimal.indication: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca from lacrimal gland sarcoidosis

dry-eye-secondary-to-reduced-blink-or-la.indication: Dry eye secondary to reduced blink or lagophthalmos

dry-eyes-from-impaired-blinking-cn-vii-i.indication: Dry eyes from impaired blinking (CN VII involvement, reduced lacrimation)

dry-eyes-and-dry-mouth-from-autonomic-dy.indication: Dry eyes and dry mouth from autonomic dysfunction

**Target CPP 60-70 mmHg** (CPP = MAP - ICP); avoid CPP <60 (ischemia) and >70 (BTF: avoid aggressive CPP >70 due to ARDS risk); **If hypotensive:** IV fluids (isotonic crystalloid; avoid hypotonic fluids); vasopressors (norepinephrine first-line); **If hypertensive with ICP crisis:** Treat ICP first (osmotherapy, sedation); avoid precipitously lowering BP (reduces CPP)

ongoing: CPP is the primary determinant of cerebral perfusion
aggressive CPP >70 increases ARDS risk without outcome benefit

neuropathic-pain.notes: Consider for lancinating/shooting pain; many drug interactions

paroxysmal-kinesigenic-dystonia-dyskines.notes: Start 100 mg BID; increase by 100-200 mg q1wk; target 400-800 mg/day; check HLA-B*1502 in at-risk populations

lancinating-shooting-pain-trigeminal-dis.notes: Start 100 mg BID; increase by 200 mg/day every 3-7 days; max 1200 mg/day

trigeminal-neuralgia-from-cn-v-sarcoidos.indication: Trigeminal neuralgia from CN V sarcoidosis
trigeminal-neuralgia-from-cn-v-sarcoidos.notes: Start 100 mg BID; titrate by 200 mg/day q3-7d; target level 4-12 mcg/mL; max 1200 mg/day

sodium-channel-blocker-limited-evidence-.indication: Sodium channel blocker; limited evidence for SFN specifically
sodium-channel-blocker-limited-evidence-.notes: Start 100 mg BID; titrate by 200 mg/wk; max 1200 mg/day

general.notes: 100-200 mg BID; increase by 100-200 mg q3-7 days; target 400-1200 mg/day divided BID-TID

trigeminal-neuralgia-lancinating-pain.notes: Start 100 mg BID; increase by 200 mg/day every 3-7 days; max 1200 mg/day

focal-epilepsy-trigeminal-neuralgia-effe.indication: Focal epilepsy; trigeminal neuralgia; effective but many drug interactions (enzyme inducer)
focal-epilepsy-trigeminal-neuralgia-effe.notes: Start 100-200 mg BID; increase by 200 mg q1wk; target 400-600 mg BID; max 1600 mg/day; use extended-release

gaze-evoked-nystagmus-and-ataxia-at-toxi.indication: Gaze-evoked nystagmus and ataxia at toxic levels; dose-dependent
gaze-evoked-nystagmus-and-ataxia-at-toxi.notes: Drug level; reduce dose; autoinduction may alter levels unpredictably

second-line-for-myotonia-if-mexiletine-n.indication: Second-line for myotonia if mexiletine not tolerated or contraindicated; sodium channel blocker
second-line-for-myotonia-if-mexiletine-n.notes: Start 100 mg PO BID; increase by 100-200 mg/week; target 400-600 mg/day divided BID-TID; max 1200 mg/day

neuropathic-pain-alternative.notes: Start 100 mg PO BID; increase by 100 mg/day q3-7 days; target 400-800 mg/day in divided doses; max 1200 mg/day

lancinating-radicular-pain-paroxysmal-ne.indication: Lancinating radicular pain; paroxysmal neuropathic pain; trigeminal component
lancinating-radicular-pain-paroxysmal-ne.notes: Start 100 mg PO BID; increase by 200 mg/day q1 week; max 1200 mg/day; use extended-release formulation

lancinating-paroxysmal-neuropathic-pain-.indication: Lancinating/paroxysmal neuropathic pain in Lyme radiculopathy (similar mechanism to trigeminal neuralgia pain) refractory to gabapentin/pregabalin
lancinating-paroxysmal-neuropathic-pain-.notes: Start 100 mg BID; titrate by 200 mg/day q1wk; target 400-800 mg/day divided BID; max 1200 mg/day

focal-seizures.notes: Start 200 mg PO BID; increase by 200 mg/day weekly; target 800-1200 mg/day; max 1600 mg/day

blackBoxWarnings: Serious dermatologic reactions (SJS/TEN) - HLA-B*1502 screening required in Asian populations
Aplastic anemia and agranulocytosis (rare but serious)
precautions: Potent CYP3A4 inducer - many drug interactions
Autoinduction - levels decrease over first 2-4 weeks

drugInteractions.effect: Reduced contraceptive efficacy - use backup method
Reduced valproate levels; increased carbamazepine epoxide

safety.lactation: Compatible but monitor infant for sedation

tiers.adjustment: 75% of normal dose; use with caution

hepaticAdjustment.notes: Reduce dose in hepatic impairment; hepatically metabolized. Avoid in severe impairment.

monitoring.frequency: CBC and sodium monthly x 3 months, then every 3-6 months

patientCounseling: Take with food to reduce GI upset
Report any rash, fever, sore throat, mouth ulcers immediately (stop drug if rash)
Do not stop abruptly - seizure risk
Many drug interactions - inform all providers
May reduce effectiveness of birth control pills
Avoid grapefruit juice

alternative-adjunctive-for-mild-moderate.indication: Alternative/adjunctive for mild-moderate withdrawal; may reduce withdrawal severity and seizure risk; evidence in European literature
alternative-adjunctive-for-mild-moderate.notes: Start 200 mg TID on day 1; may increase to 400 mg TID; taper over 5-7 days; can be used alone for mild withdrawal or as adjunct

general.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks; usual maintenance 300-800 mg levodopa/day

levodopa-responsiveness-trial-required-b.indication: Levodopa responsiveness trial; required by MDS criteria for akinetic-rigid parkinsonism
levodopa-responsiveness-trial-required-b.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks to 25/250 mg TID; adequate trial requires 800-1000 mg levodopa/day for ≥1 month; document response

ongoing: Nausea, orthostatic hypotension, dyskinesia (rare in PSP)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa CR (Sinemet CR) 25/100 CR qHS PO
Carbidopa-Levodopa CR (Sinemet CR) 50/200 CR BID PO

nocturnal-symptoms-wearing-off.notes: 25/100 to 50/200 CR at bedtime or BID; 70% bioavailability vs IR

motor-fluctuations-extend-levodopa-effec.notes: Convert from IR using manufacturer table; typically TID dosing

general.notes: Continuous infusion via PEG-J; specialist prescribing

motor-symptoms-first-line-dopaminergic-t.notes: Start 25/100 TID; titrate by 1 tablet q1-2wk; typical target 25/100-25/250 TID

parkinsonism-in-msa-p-levodopa-trial-req.indication: Parkinsonism in MSA-P — levodopa trial required for diagnosis (poor response expected in most)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Carbidopa/Levodopa (Sinemet) — therapeutic trial 25/100 mg TID PO
Carbidopa/Levodopa (Sinemet) — therapeutic trial 25/250 mg TID PO

parkinsonism-in-msa-p-levodopa-trial-req.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate to 25/250 mg TID over 4-8 weeks; up to 1000-1500 mg levodopa/day to document response; ~30% have partial/transient response

ongoing: Orthostatic BP (levodopa may worsen OH), nausea, dyskinesia (especially facial/cervical in MSA), motor response assessment using UPDRS

shunt-infection-empiric-gram-negative-co.notes: 2 g IV q8h; adjust for renal function

alternative-parenteral-beta-lactam-for-n.indication: Alternative parenteral beta-lactam for neuroborreliosis when ceftriaxone is contraindicated (biliary disease) or unavailable; equivalent CNS penetration

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cefotaxime (alternative to ceftriaxone) 2 g q8h IV

alternative-parenteral-beta-lactam-for-n.notes: 2 g IV every 8 hours for 14-28 days

pending-csf-culture-results-empiric-bact.indication: Pending CSF culture results; empiric bacterial meningitis coverage

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone (empiric if bacterial meningitis not excluded) 2g IV

pending-csf-culture-results-empiric-bact.notes: 2g IV q12h; continue until CSF cultures negative at 48-72h

empiric-meningitis-coverage-pending-csf-.indication: Empiric meningitis coverage pending CSF results (give BEFORE LP if delay anticipated)
empiric-meningitis-coverage-pending-csf-.notes: 2 g IV q12h (meningitis dosing); give STAT if bacterial meningitis suspected

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone (if intermediate or unknown sensitivity) 2 g IV

s-pneumoniae-intermediate.notes: 2 g IV q12h; continue vancomycin until sensitivities confirm

e-coli-gram-negative.notes: 2 g IV q12h; adjust per sensitivities

empiric-broad-spectrum-coverage-for-stre.indication: Empiric broad-spectrum coverage for Streptococci, gram-negatives, H. influenzae; penetrates blood-brain barrier well
empiric-broad-spectrum-coverage-for-stre.notes: 2 g IV q12h; duration 6-8 weeks total IV therapy; adjust based on culture results

febrile-thunderclap-headache-with-mening.indication: Febrile thunderclap headache with meningeal signs — empiric gram-negative and pneumococcal coverage

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone (if bacterial meningitis suspected) (CPT 96374) 2 g IV

febrile-thunderclap-headache-with-mening.notes: Ceftriaxone 2 g IV q12h. Do NOT delay antibiotics for LP or imaging

first-line-treatment-for-neuroborreliosi.indication: First-line treatment for neuroborreliosis with CNS involvement (meningitis, encephalomyelitis, encephalopathy) and cranial neuropathy with CSF pleocytosis; also for Lyme radiculopathy with CSF abnormalities
first-line-treatment-for-neuroborreliosi.notes: 2 g IV once daily for 14-28 days (most experts recommend 14-21 days); infuse over 30-60 min; standard duration 14 days for most cases, 21-28 days for late neuroborreliosis or encephalomyelitis

contraindications: caution with biliary disease (ceftriaxone can cause biliary sludge/pseudolithiasis)

ceftriaxone-iv.name: Ceftriaxone IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96374)

empiric-bacterial-coverage-covers-s-pneu.indication: Empiric bacterial coverage; covers S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae, gram-negatives; continue until CSF cultures negative at 48-72h and BioFire negative for bacteria

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96374) 2 g IV

empiric-bacterial-coverage-covers-s-pneu.notes: 2 g IV q12h; start within 30 minutes of presentation; discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded (negative Gram stain + negative BioFire + CSF consistent with viral + cultures negative at 48-72h)

alternative-for-neurosyphilis-when-penic.indication: Alternative for neurosyphilis when penicillin desensitization is not feasible; CDC-recommended alternative. Evidence supports adequate CSF penetration and treponemicidal activity

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone IV (alternative to penicillin G) 2 g daily IV

alternative-for-neurosyphilis-when-penic.notes: 2 g IV daily for 10-14 days. Some experts recommend 14 days. Limited clinical trial data but supported by observational studies and CDC guidelines

general.notes: 2 g IV daily × 14-21 days (if CNS involvement)

contraindications: Cephalosporin allergy (cross-reactivity low with penicillin allergy)
Cephalosporin allergy (true anaphylaxis — use chloramphenicol or meropenem as alternative)
severe penicillin allergy with cephalosporin cross-reactivity (low risk, ~1-2%)

dre-adjunctive-therapy-novel-mechanism-s.indication: DRE adjunctive therapy; novel mechanism (sodium channel + GABA-A positive allosteric modulator); demonstrated high responder rates in trials
dre-adjunctive-therapy-novel-mechanism-s.notes: Start 12.5 mg daily x 2 weeks → 25 mg daily x 2 weeks → 50 mg daily x 2 weeks → 100 mg daily x 2 weeks → 150 mg daily x 2 weeks → 200 mg daily; max 400 mg daily; TITRATE SLOWLY (DRESS risk)

focal-epilepsy-high-efficacy-in-drug-res.indication: Focal epilepsy; high efficacy in drug-resistant cases; dual mechanism
focal-epilepsy-high-efficacy-in-drug-res.notes: Start 12.5 mg daily; titrate per REMS schedule over 11+ weeks to target 200 mg daily; max 400 mg; SLOW TITRATION MANDATORY

adjunctive-for-focal.notes: Start 12.5 mg daily Ã— 2 weeks; titrate slowly per package insert; target 200-400 mg daily

contraindications: QT shortening with familial short QT

ongoing: ASM level interactions (reduce clobazam, phenytoin, phenobarbital)
ECG at baseline and after reaching 200 mg
monitor for DRESS (rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia)

general.notes: Erenumab 70-140 mg SC monthly; Fremanezumab 225 mg monthly or 675 mg quarterly; Galcanezumab 240 mg load then 120 mg monthly

symptom-triggered-withdrawal-management-.indication: Symptom-triggered withdrawal management (CIWA-Ar based); preferred for mild-moderate withdrawal when oral route available
symptom-triggered-withdrawal-management-.notes: CIWA-Ar >=10: give 25-100 mg PO q1h until CIWA <10; then PRN dosing; typical total day 1: 200-400 mg; taper over 3-5 days; long half-life provides smooth coverage

ongoing: CIWA-Ar q1h during active treatment, then q4h when stable

second-line-dopamine-antagonist-effectiv.indication: Second-line dopamine antagonist; effective for refractory acute headache
second-line-dopamine-antagonist-effectiv.notes: 12.5 mg IV in 500 mL NS over 20 min; repeat 25 mg in 30 min if needed; co-administer diphenhydramine

alternative-dopamine-antagonist-with-pot.indication: Alternative dopamine antagonist with potent analgesic and sedative effect for refractory migraine

doseOptions.orderSentence: Chlorpromazine IV 12.5 mg IV once IV
Chlorpromazine IV 25 mg IV once IV

alternative-dopamine-antagonist-with-pot.notes: 12.5-25 mg IV over 20 min with 500 mL NS bolus; may repeat x2 q30min; max 75 mg

contraindications: QT prolongation, severe hypotension, Parkinson disease

ongoing: BP q15min (orthostatic hypotension common), QTc, sedation

thiazide-like-diuretic-for-bp-control-ef.indication: Thiazide-like diuretic for BP control; effective for stroke prevention
thiazide-like-diuretic-for-bp-control-ef.notes: Start 12.5 mg daily; may increase to 25 mg daily

thiazide-like-diuretic-for-post-stroke-b.indication: Thiazide-like diuretic for post-stroke BP management; more potent and longer-acting than HCTZ; evidence from ALLHAT
thiazide-like-diuretic-for-post-stroke-b.notes: Start 12.5 mg daily; increase to 25 mg if needed; max 25 mg; take in morning

vitamin-d-deficiency-is-prevalent-in-icu.indication: Vitamin D deficiency is prevalent in ICU patients and contributes to muscle weakness
vitamin-d-deficiency-is-prevalent-in-icu.notes: 2000 IU PO daily for maintenance; 50,000 IU PO weekly x 8 weeks if deficient (<20 ng/mL), then 2000 IU daily

antiplatelet-with-vasodilatory-propertie.notes: Start 50 mg BID; increase to 100 mg BID if tolerated; take 30 min before or 2h after meals

inhibits-cyp3a4-metabolism-of-praziquant.notes: 400 mg PO TID; start 1-2 days before praziquantel; continue throughout praziquantel course

refractory-shivering-despite-first-line-.indication: Refractory shivering despite first-line measures during TTM; note: obscures clinical exam and must be discontinued well before prognostication
refractory-shivering-despite-first-line-.notes: 0.15 mg/kg IV bolus, then 1-3 mcg/kg/min infusion; titrate to train-of-four 1-2/4

ongoing: cEEG mandatory when paralyzed (seizures undetectable clinically)

dose-dependent-irreversible-cochlear-tox.indication: Dose-dependent irreversible cochlear toxicity; high-frequency SNHL and tinnitus
dose-dependent-irreversible-cochlear-tox.notes: Irreversible ototoxicity; no proven otoprotectant; cisplatin more ototoxic than carboplatin

ongoing: Baseline and serial audiometry during treatment

depression-agitation-in-dementia.notes: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg in elderly due to QT prolongation risk

depression-anxiety-good-tolerability.notes: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg/day due to QTc risk

depression-contributing-to-cognitive-sym.indication: Depression contributing to cognitive symptoms (pseudodementia component)
depression-contributing-to-cognitive-sym.notes: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg in elderly due to QT risk

general.notes: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg (QT risk at higher doses)

depression-anxiety-compulsive-behaviors.notes: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg in elderly due to QT prolongation risk

depression-mild-moderate-agitation.notes: Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg in elderly due to QT prolongation risk

ongoing: ECG at baseline if cardiac risk
QTc at baseline and if dose >20 mg

general.notes: Year 1: 1.75 mg/kg divided into 2 treatment weeks (week 1 and week 5); Year 2: repeat same dosing; no treatment years 3-4

ongoing: CBC at months 2 and 6 of each treatment year

adjunctive-for-refractory-seizures.notes: Start 5-10 mg BID; titrate to 20-40 mg/day in divided doses

adjunctive-therapy.notes: Start 5-10 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg weekly; max 40 mg/day in divided doses

general.notes: Start 5-10 mg BID; titrate to 20-40 mg/day in divided doses

ongoing: CYP2C19 poor metabolizers need lower dose

potent-anticataplectic-agent-tricyclic-a.indication: Potent anticataplectic agent; tricyclic antidepressant with strong REM-suppressive properties

adjunct-for-chorea-also-helps-myoclonus-.indication: Adjunct for chorea; also helps myoclonus and anxiety

adjunct-for-dystonia-myoclonus-dystonia.notes: Start 0.25 mg BID; increase by 0.25-0.5 mg q3-7d; typical 1-4 mg/day; max 6 mg/day

general.notes: 0.5 mg TID; titrate to 2-4 mg/day

adjunct-for-tic-suppression-also-treats-.indication: Adjunct for tic suppression; also treats comorbid anxiety

myoclonus-cjd.notes: 0.5 mg PO BID; increase to 1-2 mg TID

second-line-for-downbeat-nystagmus-gabae.indication: Second-line for downbeat nystagmus; GABAergic effect on vestibular nuclei

symptomatic-relief-of-oscillopsia-from-s.indication: Symptomatic relief of oscillopsia from see-saw nystagmus; limited evidence; trial basis
symptomatic-relief-of-oscillopsia-from-s.notes: **Clonazepam 0.5 mg PO BID, titrate to max 1 mg TID**

rem-sleep-behavior-disorder-rbd-second-l.indication: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) — second-line if melatonin insufficient; highly effective

rem-sleep-behavior-disorder.notes: Start 0.25-0.5 mg qHS; titrate to effect; typical 0.5-1 mg

tremor-dystonia-chorea-sleep-disturbance.notes: Start 0.5 mg BID; titrate by 0.5 mg q3-5 days; max 4 mg/day

adjunct-may-help-in-some-patients.indication: Adjunct; may help in some patients

first-line-medication-alpha-2-agonist-fo.indication: First-line medication; alpha-2 agonist for tics; also treats comorbid ADHD and insomnia
first-line-medication-alpha-2-agonist-fo.notes: Start 0.05 mg qHS; increase by 0.05 mg q3-7d; target 0.1-0.3 mg/day divided BID-QID; max 0.4 mg/day

alternative-delivery-improved-compliance.indication: Alternative delivery; improved compliance; steady-state levels
alternative-delivery-improved-compliance.notes: Start 0.1 mg/24hr patch; increase by 0.1 mg q1-2wk; max 0.3 mg/24hr; change patch weekly

alternative-to-aspirin-if-aspirin-intole.indication: Alternative to aspirin if aspirin-intolerant; or after DAPT period

alternative-antiplatelet-for-aspirin-int.indication: Alternative antiplatelet for aspirin-intolerant patients; long-term secondary prevention post-dissection
alternative-antiplatelet-for-aspirin-int.notes: 75 mg PO daily; duration minimum 3-6 months; if aspirin intolerant, may use long-term

alternative-to-aspirin-if-aspirin-intole.indication: Alternative to aspirin if aspirin-intolerant; DAPT with aspirin for 21 days after minor stroke/TIA (CHANCE/POINT protocol)

alternative-to-aspirin-if-aspirin-intole.indication: Alternative to aspirin if aspirin-intolerant; component of DAPT for 21 days after minor stroke/TIA per CHANCE/POINT; perioperative use with CEA

CYP2C19 poor metabolizer (reduced efficacy — use ticagrelor)

antipsychotic-with-lowest-eps-risk-for-t.indication: Antipsychotic with lowest EPS risk; for treatment-refractory psychosis requiring continued antipsychotic

refractory-psychosis-best-evidence-but-m.indication: Refractory psychosis; best evidence but monitoring required

ANC weekly x 6 months, then biweekly x 6 months, then monthly

coq10-deficiency-primary-cerebellar-atax.indication: CoQ10 deficiency (primary cerebellar ataxia responsive to supplementation); may benefit some mitochondrial ataxias

adjunctive-preventive-level-c-evidence-n.indication: Adjunctive preventive; Level C evidence; nutraceutical
adjunctive-preventive-level-c-evidence-n.notes: 100 mg PO TID (300 mg/day total); may take 3 months for full effect

recurrent-oral-genital-ulcers-mucocutane.indication: Recurrent oral/genital ulcers; mucocutaneous Behcet's manifestations (adjunct to CNS treatment)
