residual-inflammatory-risk-lodoco2-colco.indication: Residual inflammatory risk (LoDoCo2 / COLCOT trials support in ACS — emerging data for stroke prevention)

inadequate-response-to-monotherapy.notes: Gabapentinoid + SNRI; TCA + gabapentinoid; use lower doses of each

combination-therapy-for-anti-mda5-ild-me.name: Combination therapy for anti-MDA5 ILD: Methylprednisolone + Tacrolimus + Cyclophosphamide

rapidly-progressive-ild-with-anti-mda5-a.indication: Rapidly progressive ILD with anti-MDA5 antibody (Tsuji triple-therapy protocol; high mortality without aggressive treatment)

doseOptions.text: Methylpred 1000 mg IV x 3d + tacrolimus 1 mg BID + CYC 500-750 mg/m2
doseOptions.orderSentence: Combination therapy for anti-MDA5 ILD: Methylprednisolone + Tacrolimus + Cyclophosphamide Methylpred 1000 mg IV x 3d + tacrolimus 1 mg BID + CYC 500-750 mg/m2 IV/PO

rapidly-progressive-ild-with-anti-mda5-a.notes: Pulse methylprednisolone 1000 mg IV x 3 days then prednisone 1 mg/kg + tacrolimus (trough 5-10 ng/mL) + IV cyclophosphamide 500-750 mg/m2 monthly; early combination improves survival

severe-refractory-attack-not-responding-.indication: Severe refractory attack not responding to steroids alone; sequential approach: PLEX first, then IVIG (PLEX removes IVIG, so give IVIG after PLEX completion)

doseOptions.text: PLEX x 5-7 exchanges then IVIG 0.4 g/kg x 5 days
doseOptions.orderSentence: Combined PLEX + IVIG (sequential) PLEX x 5-7 exchanges then IVIG 0.4 g/kg x 5 days Extracorporeal/IV

severe-refractory-attack-not-responding-.notes: PLEX x 5-7 exchanges, then IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days starting at least 24 hours after final PLEX exchange

general.notes: If patient declines intubation or chronic mechanical ventilation; opioids for dyspnea (morphine 2-5 mg IV/SQ q2-4h PRN — does NOT hasten death and relieves suffering); anxiolytics (lorazepam); comfort measures; hospice referral

ongoing: Dyspnea is the most distressing symptom at end of life
do not withhold for fear of "hastening death"

first-line-for-all-tic-disorders-causing.indication: First-line for all tic disorders causing functional impairment; AAN Level A recommendation

doseOptions.orderSentence: Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) (CPT 90834-90837) 8 sessions In-person

first-line-for-all-tic-disorders-causing.notes: 8 sessions over 10 weeks; includes psychoeducation, habit reversal training (awareness training + competing response), relaxation techniques, and function-based assessment

ongoing: YGTSS score at baseline and after completion

bridge-therapy-while-awaiting-definitive.indication: Bridge therapy while awaiting definitive treatment; refractory symptoms

doseOptions.orderSentence: Continuous epidural saline infusion NS at 20-50 mL/hr Epidural

bridge-therapy-while-awaiting-definitive.notes: Continuous epidural normal saline infusion at 20-50 mL/hr via epidural catheter; temporary measure for severe refractory symptoms

ongoing: Catheter site infection, neurologic exam, headache response

non-hormonal-contraception-alternative-w.indication: Non-hormonal contraception; alternative when hormonal methods not desired; NOT affected by ASMs

doseOptions.orderSentence: Copper IUD (Paragard) N/A — device placement IUD

non-hormonal-contraception-alternative-w.notes: Place copper IUD; completely unaffected by ASM interactions; non-hormonal option

copper-deficiency-myelopathy-and-ataxia-.indication: Copper deficiency myelopathy and ataxia (zinc excess, bariatric surgery, malabsorption)
copper-deficiency-myelopathy-and-ataxia-.notes: Acute: 2 mg IV daily x 5 days; Maintenance: 2 mg PO daily; remove cause (e.g., stop excess zinc)

contraindications: Wilson disease (must be excluded before copper supplementation)

ongoing: Serum copper and ceruloplasmin q3 months

general.notes: 100 mg TID

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Correct electrolyte abnormalities** Per specific electrolyte IV

hyponatremia-hypomagnesemia-hypocalcemia.notes: **Hyponatremia:** Correct slowly (max 8-10 mEq/L per 24h to avoid osmotic demyelination); **Hypomagnesemia:** MgSO4 2-4 g IV over 30-60 min then maintenance; **Hypocalcemia:** Calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV

contraindications: Overcorrection of sodium — osmotic demyelination syndrome

exclude-metabolic-confounders-sodium-glu.indication: Exclude metabolic confounders; sodium, glucose, pH, calcium must be within acceptable ranges

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Correction of metabolic derangements** Per derangement IV

exclude-metabolic-confounders-sodium-glu.notes: Correct sodium to 115-160 mEq/L range; glucose >54 mg/dL (D50 50 mL if needed); correct severe acidosis (NaHCO3 if pH <7.2); correct severe hypocalcemia (calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV); correct hypothyroidism

contraindications: Overly rapid sodium correction (risk of osmotic demyelination — less relevant in brain death but important for organ preservation)

minimize-corticosteroid-exposure-as-majo.indication: Minimize corticosteroid exposure as major risk factor for CIM; taper to lowest effective dose as rapidly as clinically feasible
minimize-corticosteroid-exposure-as-majo.notes: Reassess corticosteroid indication daily; taper to lowest effective dose; discontinue if not clearly indicated; avoid concurrent use with NMBAs when possible

contraindications: Do not abruptly discontinue if patient has been on >7 days (adrenal suppression risk)

ongoing: adrenal function if tapering after prolonged course

general.notes: **CAUTION: Steroids can cause TRANSIENT WORSENING in MG (up to 50% of patients)**; **In crisis:** Start AFTER IVIG/PLEX initiated and patient stabilizing (days 3-5 or later); do NOT start steroids as initial therapy in crisis; **Protocol:** Prednisone 10-20 mg daily, increase by 10 mg every 3-5 days to 1 mg/kg/day (max 60-80 mg); OR IV methylprednisolone 1g daily x 3-5 days then oral

adjunctive-anti-inflammatory-therapy-for.indication: Adjunctive anti-inflammatory therapy for ocular syphilis (uveitis, optic neuritis, retinal vasculitis) or otic syphilis to prevent permanent vision/hearing loss; used in addition to IV penicillin, not as standalone

doseOptions.orderSentence: Corticosteroids (adjunctive for ocular/otic syphilis) 1 mg/kg daily PO

adjunctive-anti-inflammatory-therapy-for.notes: Prednisone 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 60 mg) with IV penicillin; taper over 2-4 weeks based on ophthalmology/ENT guidance; or IV methylprednisolone 250 mg q6h x 3 days then oral taper for severe cases

ongoing: Glucose, BP, bone density, weight, infection
Steroids are maintenance therapy but can worsen MG acutely ("steroid dip")
always start with IVIG or PLEX first in crisis

modest-improvement-in-muscle-strength-an.indication: Modest improvement in muscle strength and endurance in IBM (limited evidence); well-tolerated nutritional supplement
modest-improvement-in-muscle-strength-an.notes: 5 g PO daily mixed in water or juice; no loading phase needed; take with meal

ongoing: Renal function at baseline and q6 months
serum creatinine (will be mildly elevated from supplement, not nephrotoxicity)

confirmed-or-suspected-b12-deficiency-wi.indication: Confirmed or suspected B12 deficiency with neurological symptoms; preferred parenteral route
confirmed-or-suspected-b12-deficiency-wi.notes: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg IM weekly x 4 weeks, then 1000 mcg IM monthly indefinitely

ongoing: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7 (reticulocyte crisis confirms response)
potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis)

if-im-injection-contraindicated-anticoag.indication: If IM injection contraindicated (anticoagulation, thrombocytopenia) or patient preference
if-im-injection-contraindicated-anticoag.notes: 1000 mcg SC daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg SC weekly x 4 weeks, then 1000 mcg SC monthly indefinitely

ongoing: potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis)

muscle-spasm-short-term.notes: 5-10 mg TID; max 30 mg/day; limit to 2-3 weeks

cervical-muscle-spasm-and-neck-pain-shor.indication: Cervical muscle spasm and neck pain; short-term adjunctive use for acute exacerbation
cervical-muscle-spasm-and-neck-pain-shor.notes: 5-10 mg PO TID; limit to 2-3 weeks; avoid in elderly

muscle-spasm-associated-with-plexopathy-.notes: 5-10 mg TID; max 30 mg/day; limit to 2-3 weeks

severe-refractory-parenchymal-nbd-with-p.indication: Severe/refractory parenchymal NBD with progressive neurological decline; brainstem syndrome not responding to steroids + azathioprine
severe-refractory-parenchymal-nbd-with-p.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly for 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA for uroprotection; follow with azathioprine maintenance

rapidly-progressive-ild-especially-anti-.indication: Rapidly progressive ILD (especially anti-MDA5); severe refractory myositis; anti-synthetase syndrome with progressive ILD
rapidly-progressive-ild-especially-anti-.notes: IV pulse: 500-1000 mg/m2 monthly x 6 months; OR low-dose Euro-Lupus protocol: 500 mg IV every 2 weeks x 6 doses; MESNA prophylaxis with each dose

general.notes: Pulse: 500-1000 mg/m² IV monthly × 6; rarely used due to toxicity

severe-refractory-he-failing-all-other-a.indication: Severe refractory HE failing all other agents
severe-refractory-he-failing-all-other-a.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly x 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA (uroprotection)

severe-refractory-neurosarcoidosis-with-.indication: Severe refractory neurosarcoidosis with progressive neurological decline despite other therapies; last resort
severe-refractory-neurosarcoidosis-with-.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly for 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA for uroprotection; consider dose reduction for renal impairment

severe-refractory-attack-failing-steroid.indication: Severe refractory attack failing steroids and PLEX
severe-refractory-attack-failing-steroid.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV single pulse; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA

vasculitic-neuropathy-severe.notes: 1-2 mg/kg/day PO OR 500-1000 mg/mÃ‚Â² IV monthly Ãƒâ€” 6 months

severe-refractory-lems-not-responding-to.indication: Severe refractory LEMS not responding to other immunosuppressants; reserved for life-threatening or disabling disease
severe-refractory-lems-not-responding-to.notes: Pulse IV 500-1000 mg/m2 monthly x 6 months; OR oral 1-2 mg/kg/day; reserved for refractory cases; MESNA uroprotection with IV dosing

severe-refractory-sps-failing-ivig-ritux.indication: Severe refractory SPS failing IVIg, rituximab, and other agents; last resort
severe-refractory-sps-failing-ivig-ritux.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly for 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA for uroprotection; adjust for renal function

second-line-immunotherapy-for-refractory.indication: Second-line immunotherapy for refractory paraneoplastic syndrome; used for intracellular antibody syndromes unresponsive to first-line
second-line-immunotherapy-for-refractory.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly x 6 cycles; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA (uroprotection)

ongoing: CBC weekly x 4 weeks after each cycle (nadir day 10-14)
CBC weekly, renal function, hemorrhagic cystitis (hydration + mesna)
urinalysis (hemorrhagic cystitis - MESNA with IV dosing)

standard-induction-therapy-for-biopsy-co.indication: Standard induction therapy for biopsy-confirmed PACNS combined with corticosteroids; most evidence-based regimen per Calabrese/Mallek criteria

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cyclophosphamide IV (induction) 750 mg/m2 monthly x 3-6 months IV

standard-induction-therapy-for-biopsy-co.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly x 3-6 months (typical 6 cycles); pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA for uroprotection; reduce dose for age >65, renal impairment, leukopenia

severe-refractory-susac-syndrome-failing.indication: Severe refractory Susac syndrome failing IVIG, steroids, and other immunosuppressants; fulminant disease with rapid progression
severe-refractory-susac-syndrome-failing.notes: 750 mg/m2 IV monthly x 3-6 months; pre-hydrate with 1L NS; administer with MESNA for uroprotection; used in severe/refractory cases only

ongoing: CBC weekly x 4 weeks after each cycle (nadir day 10-14)
cumulative dose tracking (lifetime max ~36g concern for malignancy)

alternative-to-iv-pulse-dosing-some-clin.indication: Alternative to IV pulse dosing; some clinicians prefer daily oral for severe/refractory disease

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cyclophosphamide PO (alternative induction) 2 mg/kg daily PO

alternative-to-iv-pulse-dosing-some-clin.notes: 2 mg/kg/day PO (max 200 mg/day); round to nearest 25 mg; duration 3-6 months then transition to maintenance

ongoing: CBC with differential weekly x 1 month, then q2 weeks
higher risk of bladder toxicity than IV pulse

drug-resistant-tb-mdr-xdr-tb-cns-penetra.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR/XDR-TB); CNS penetration adequate; frequent neuropsychiatric side effects
drug-resistant-tb-mdr-xdr-tb-cns-penetra.notes: 250 mg PO BID initially, increase to 500 mg BID; max 1000 mg/day; take with pyridoxine 50-100 mg daily

general.notes: Start 2-3 mg/kg/day PO in 2 divided doses; target trough 100-200 ng/mL; onset 3-6 months

refractory-ocular-and-neurological-behce.indication: Refractory ocular and neurological Behcet's; often combined with azathioprine; effective for uveitis; **CAUTION: use with concurrent azathioprine only -- monotherapy worsens CNS disease**
refractory-ocular-and-neurological-behce.notes: Start 3-5 mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses; adjust per trough level (target 100-200 ng/mL)

alternative-to-tacrolimus-similar-effica.notes: 3-5 mg/kg/day divided BID; adjust to trough 100-200 ng/mL

alternative-steroid-sparing-agent-for-a-.indication: Alternative steroid-sparing agent for A-LEMS; faster onset than azathioprine (2-6 months)
alternative-steroid-sparing-agent-for-a-.notes: Start 2-3 mg/kg/day divided BID; target trough 100-150 ng/mL; onset 2-6 months

ongoing: Trough levels, Cr, BP, Mg, lipids monthly
renal function q2 weeks then monthly

component-of-matrix-regimen-mtx-ara-c-th.indication: Component of MATRix regimen (MTX, Ara-C, Thiotepa, Rituximab); high-dose achieves therapeutic CSF levels; consolidation in younger patients

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cytarabine (high-dose, MATRix regimen component) 2 g/m2 IV

component-of-matrix-regimen-mtx-ara-c-th.notes: 2 g/m2 IV over 3h q12h on Days 2-3 (4 doses total per cycle); corticosteroid eye drops (dexamethasone 0.1% q6h) starting 12h before and continuing 48h after to prevent chemical conjunctivitis; cerebellar function assessment before each dose

contraindications: Cerebellar exam before each dose (finger-to-nose, rapid alternating movements, tandem gait)
if ANY cerebellar signs develop, STOP immediately (irreversible)

wilson-s-disease-with-neurological-sympt.notes: Start 250 mg daily; increase by 250 mg q4-7d; target 1000-1500 mg/day divided BID (take 1hr before meals); lifelong treatment

wilson-disease-confirmed-first-line-copp.indication: Wilson disease confirmed; first-line copper chelation therapy
wilson-disease-confirmed-first-line-copp.notes: Start 250 mg daily; increase by 250 mg q4-7d to target 1000-1500 mg/day divided QID; take on empty stomach 1 hour before meals; pyridoxine 25 mg daily supplementation required

first-line-chelation-symptomatic-wd-hepa.indication: First-line chelation (symptomatic WD — hepatic or neurologic); removes copper via renal excretion
first-line-chelation-symptomatic-wd-hepa.notes: Start 250-500 mg/day; increase by 250 mg every 4-7 days; target 1000-1500 mg/day divided BID-QID; take on empty stomach (1h before or 2h after meals); SLOW titration reduces neurologic worsening risk

ongoing: 24h urine copper q3-6 months (target 200-500 mcg/24h on treatment)
CBC q2 weeks for first 3 months then monthly
CBC weekly x1 month then monthly x6 months then q3 months
CBC weekly x1mo then monthly x6mo then q3mo
UA for proteinuria every 2 weeks x3 months then monthly
neurologic monitoring for initial worsening (up to 50% of patients)
watch for neurologic WORSENING in first 6-8 weeks (occurs in 10-50%)

alternative-to-warfarin-for-cvt-re-spect.indication: Alternative to warfarin for CVT (RE-SPECT CVT trial); no INR monitoring needed
alternative-to-warfarin-for-cvt-re-spect.notes: 150 mg PO BID; reduce to 110 mg BID if age >80, concurrent P-gp inhibitor, or CrCl 30-50

general.notes: 150 mg PO BID (75 mg BID if CrCl 15-30); start 4-14 days post-stroke for AF

anticoagulation-for-stroke-with-af-re-ly.indication: Anticoagulation for stroke with AF; RE-LY trial; reversible with idarucizumab
anticoagulation-for-stroke-with-af-re-ly.notes: 150 mg BID standard; 110 mg BID if age ≥80 or concurrent P-gp inhibitor; CrCl 30-50: 150 mg BID acceptable; avoid if CrCl <30

ongoing: thrombin time or ecarin clotting time if needed

general.notes: 5 g IV (two 2.5g boluses or infusions). Specific reversal agent for dabigatran. Reversal within minutes

refractory-spasms-with-hyperthermia-or-m.indication: Refractory spasms with hyperthermia or malignant hyperthermia-like presentation during severe SPS crisis
refractory-spasms-with-hyperthermia-or-m.notes: 1-2.5 mg/kg IV push; may repeat q5-10 min; max 10 mg/kg; transition to PO 25-100 mg QID when stabilized

spasticity-refractory-to-baclofen-and-ti.indication: Spasticity refractory to baclofen and tizanidine; acts peripherally on muscle
spasticity-refractory-to-baclofen-and-ti.notes: Start 25 mg PO daily; increase by 25 mg q4-7 days; max 400 mg/day divided TID-QID

contraindications: severely impaired cardiac or pulmonary function

ongoing: LFTs at baseline, then monthly for first 6 months

intracranial-stenosis-70-99-sammpris-tri.notes: Aspirin 325 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg daily x 90 days; then single antiplatelet + aggressive risk factor management

pi-with-moderate-cpe-boosted-pi-for-resi.indication: PI with moderate CPE; boosted PI for resistant virus; use when INSTI resistance present
pi-with-moderate-cpe-boosted-pi-for-resi.notes: 800 mg darunavir + 100 mg ritonavir PO daily with food; 600/100 mg BID if resistance

deep-brain-stimulation-of-anterior-nucle.name: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) of anterior nucleus of thalamus

dre-with-focal-epilepsy-when-resection-r.indication: DRE with focal epilepsy when resection/RNS not feasible; SANTE trial showed ~69% seizure reduction at 5 years

doseOptions.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) of anterior nucleus of thalamus N/A — device implantation Surgical

dre-with-focal-epilepsy-when-resection-r.notes: Bilateral electrodes in anterior nucleus of thalamus; parameters optimized over months; typically cycling stimulation

contraindications: caution in patients with pre-existing psychiatric disorders

definitive-treatment-for-eclampsia-deliv.indication: **DEFINITIVE TREATMENT for eclampsia**: Delivery of fetus and placenta cures eclampsia in most cases
definitive-treatment-for-eclampsia-deliv.notes: Plan delivery after maternal stabilization (seizure control + BP control); ≥34 weeks: delivery recommended; <34 weeks: consider steroids for fetal lung maturity if maternal condition allows 24-48h delay; emergent C-section if fetal distress

tca-with-minimal-anticholinergic-effects.notes: Start 25 mg qHS; titrate by 25 mg q1-2wk; target 50-100 mg

neuropathic-pain-second-line.notes: Start 25 mg qHS; increase by 25 mg weekly; max 150 mg daily

diabetes-insipidus-treatment-common-in-b.indication: Diabetes insipidus treatment (common in brain death due to pituitary failure); maintain hemodynamic stability for valid examination
diabetes-insipidus-treatment-common-in-b.notes: 1-4 mcg IV q6-12h; titrate to urine output <200-300 mL/hr; may also give 10-20 mcg intranasally; onset IV: 15-30 min; adjust based on urine output and sodium

diabetes-insipidus-treatment-maintain-eu.indication: Diabetes insipidus treatment; maintain euvolemia and sodium homeostasis for organ preservation; most brain-dead patients develop DI
diabetes-insipidus-treatment-maintain-eu.notes: 1-4 mcg IV q6-12h PRN; titrate to urine output 0.5-3 mL/kg/hr; target sodium 135-155 mEq/L; may also give 10-20 mcg intranasally

central-diabetes-insipidus-from-hypothal.indication: Central diabetes insipidus from hypothalamic/posterior pituitary sarcoidosis
central-diabetes-insipidus-from-hypothal.notes: 1-2 mcg IV/SC q12h; or 10-20 mcg intranasal BID; titrate to urine output and serum sodium

nocturnal-polyuria-contributing-to-morni.indication: Nocturnal polyuria contributing to morning OH
nocturnal-polyuria-contributing-to-morni.notes: 0.1-0.2 mg PO at bedtime; OR 10 mcg intranasal at bedtime; reduces nocturnal urine production

ongoing: Serum sodium (check at 1 week, 1 month, then q3 months), weight, fluid balance
Sodium at baseline, 1 week, 1 month, then periodically

fda-approved-for-hd-chorea-better-tolera.indication: FDA-approved for HD chorea; better tolerability than tetrabenazine
fda-approved-for-hd-chorea-better-tolera.notes: Start 6 mg daily; increase by 6 mg/wk; max 48 mg/day (24 mg per dose)

longer-half-life-alternative-to-tetraben.notes: Start 6 mg BID; increase by 6 mg/day weekly; max 48 mg/day

fda-approved-first-line-for-td-vmat2-inh.indication: FDA-approved first-line for TD; VMAT2 inhibitor
fda-approved-first-line-for-td-vmat2-inh.notes: Start 6 mg BID (12 mg/day); increase by 6 mg/day weekly; max 48 mg/day; take with food

vmat2-inhibitor-better-tolerated-than-te.indication: VMAT2 inhibitor; better tolerated than tetrabenazine; longer half-life
vmat2-inhibitor-better-tolerated-than-te.notes: Start 6 mg daily; increase by 6 mg/day weekly; target 12-48 mg/day divided BID; max 48 mg/day; take with food

ongoing: QTc at baseline and dose changes
may be better tolerated than tetrabenazine

cerebral-edema-from-parenchymal-mass-lik.indication: Cerebral edema from parenchymal mass-like lesion; acute elevated ICP
cerebral-edema-from-parenchymal-mass-lik.notes: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV q6h; taper over days-weeks as clinically improving

vasogenic-edema-from-tumor-symptomatic-m.indication: Vasogenic edema from tumor; symptomatic mass effect; reduce peritumoral edema to improve neurologic function
vasogenic-edema-from-tumor-symptomatic-m.notes: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; moderate symptoms: 4-8 mg/day; severe edema/herniation: 10 mg IV bolus then 4-8 mg q6h (up to 16-24 mg/day); taper as soon as clinically feasible over 2-4 weeks; GI prophylaxis with PPI while on steroids; symptomatic improvement typically within 24-72h

transition-from-iv-to-po-taper-as-soon-a.indication: Transition from IV to PO; taper as soon as clinically feasible to minimize steroid side effects; taper after surgery and/or after radiation
transition-from-iv-to-po-taper-as-soon-a.notes: Taper by 2 mg every 3-5 days (e.g., 16 to 12 to 8 to 6 to 4 to 2 to 1 to off); slower taper if symptoms recur; monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >3 weeks of use

adjunctive-with-empiric-antibiotics-for-.indication: Adjunctive with empiric antibiotics for suspected bacterial meningitis
adjunctive-with-empiric-antibiotics-for-.notes: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h x 4 days; give first dose BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose

iris-management-in-hiv-patients-who-deve.indication: IRIS management in HIV patients who develop worsening symptoms after ART initiation; NOT recommended as routine adjunct in cryptococcal meningitis (unlike bacterial meningitis — dexamethasone INCREASED mortality in cryptococcal meningitis per ACTA trial)
iris-management-in-hiv-patients-who-deve.notes: 0.3 mg/kg/day IV (or equivalent) for IRIS only; taper over 2-6 weeks based on clinical response; use ONLY for IRIS, NOT for routine cryptococcal meningitis

general.notes: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h x 4 days — give empirically with antibiotics until bacterial meningitis excluded. Discontinue when bacterial excluded. Role in HSV encephalitis itself is CONTROVERSIAL — some evidence for reducing edema but no clear mortality benefit; not standard of care for isolated HSV

give-empirically-with-antibiotics-greate.indication: Give empirically with antibiotics; greatest benefit if bacterial meningitis (especially S. pneumoniae); discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (adjunctive — give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose) 0.15 mg/kg IV

give-empirically-with-antibiotics-greate.notes: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h (typically 10 mg IV q6h) x 4 days; MUST be given BEFORE or simultaneously with first antibiotic dose; discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded; no proven benefit in viral meningitis

reduces-24-72h-headache-recurrence-recom.indication: Reduces 24-72h headache recurrence; recommended adjunct to ED headache cocktail

cerebral-edema-from-granulomatous-mass-l.indication: Cerebral edema from granulomatous mass lesion; acute elevated ICP
cerebral-edema-from-granulomatous-mass-l.notes: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV q6h; taper over days-weeks as clinically improving

vasogenic-edema-from-leptomeningeal-dise.indication: Vasogenic edema from leptomeningeal disease; symptomatic relief of headache, nausea, cranial neuropathies; bridge to definitive treatment
vasogenic-edema-from-leptomeningeal-dise.notes: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; moderate symptoms 4-8 mg/day; severe symptoms/herniation 10 mg IV then 4-8 mg q6h (up to 16-24 mg/day); begin taper once definitive treatment initiated; GI prophylaxis with PPI while on steroids

vasogenic-edema-with-herniation-risk-or-.indication: Vasogenic edema with herniation risk or severe mass effect ONLY when biopsy cannot be performed within 24-48h; steroids cause rapid tumor regression making biopsy non-diagnostic

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (ONLY if life-threatening herniation or biopsy not immediately available) 10 mg IV

vasogenic-edema-with-herniation-risk-or-.notes: 10 mg IV bolus, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; use LOWEST effective dose for SHORTEST duration; document that steroids were given and inform neurosurgeon and neuro-oncologist; biopsy should proceed ASAP even after steroids (may need repeat biopsy if non-diagnostic)

transition-from-iv-to-po-after-biopsy-ob.indication: Transition from IV to PO after biopsy obtained; taper as soon as clinically feasible; PCNSL often dramatically steroid-responsive; rapid taper once chemotherapy begins (MTX preferred without steroids)
transition-from-iv-to-po-after-biopsy-ob.notes: Taper by 2 mg every 3-5 days (e.g., 16 to 12 to 8 to 6 to 4 to 2 to 1 to off); PCNSL may regrow during taper; definitive chemotherapy should start before taper is complete if possible

reduce-headache-recurrence-anti-inflamma.indication: Reduce headache recurrence; anti-inflammatory effect for suspected inflammatory etiology

reduce-inflammation-and-improve-outcomes.indication: Reduce inflammation and improve outcomes in bacterial meningitis (give BEFORE or with first antibiotic dose)
reduce-inflammation-and-improve-outcomes.notes: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h x 4 days (typically 10 mg q6h); start before or with first antibiotic dose

significant-vasogenic-edema-surrounding-.indication: Significant vasogenic edema surrounding venous infarction; NOT routine
significant-vasogenic-edema-surrounding-.notes: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV q6h; taper over 5-7 days

pre-treatment-corticosteroid-before-anti.indication: Pre-treatment corticosteroid BEFORE antiparasitic therapy; reduces treatment-induced inflammation from cyst degeneration; essential for cysticercal encephalitis; subarachnoid NCC with arachnoiditis
pre-treatment-corticosteroid-before-anti.notes: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h (typically 4-8 mg q6h); start 1-2 days BEFORE antiparasitic drugs; taper over 2-4 weeks based on clinical response; longer courses for subarachnoid NCC; dexamethasone increases albendazole sulfoxide levels by 50%

vasogenic-edema-from-cerebellar-mass-tum.indication: Vasogenic edema from cerebellar mass (tumor, abscess); NOT for cytotoxic edema (stroke)
vasogenic-edema-from-cerebellar-mass-tum.notes: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV q6h; for tumor/abscess-related edema only

acute-severe-radiculopathy-disc-herniati.indication: Acute severe radiculopathy, disc herniation with inflammation

Dry mouth (paradoxical thick secretions), constipation, urinary retention
Dry mouth (therapeutic), urinary retention, constipation, tachycardia

contraindications: Pulmonary edema (restrict fluids, add diuretics if lung preservation critical)

gradual-asm-taper.name: Gradual ASM taper (levetiracetam, lamotrigine, valproic acid, etc.)

confirmed-pnes-on-carbamazepine-or-oxcar.indication: Confirmed PNES on carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine without comorbid epilepsy

ongoing: sodium level (hyponatremia more common with oxcarbazepine -- may resolve with taper)

confirmed-pnes-on-lamotrigine-without-co.indication: Confirmed PNES on lamotrigine without comorbid epilepsy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual ASM taper -- lamotrigine 25-50 mg reduction PO

confirmed-pnes-on-levetiracetam-without-.indication: Confirmed PNES on levetiracetam without comorbid epilepsy; taper AFTER definitive vEEG diagnosis

do NOT taper without epileptologist input in dual-diagnosis patients

ongoing: mood (levetiracetam withdrawal may improve mood or cause rebound anxiety)
verify no epileptiform events during taper

confirmed-pnes-on-phenobarbital-without-.indication: Confirmed PNES on phenobarbital without comorbid epilepsy; REQUIRES SLOW TAPER (barbiturate withdrawal risk)

contraindications: barbiturate dependence (consider inpatient taper for high doses >120 mg/day)

ongoing: withdrawal symptoms (anxiety, insomnia, tremor, TRUE seizures)

general.notes: **For refractory ICP crisis**; 30 mL IV bolus via central line; can repeat; target sodium up to 155-160 mEq/L in refractory cases (with close monitoring); **Risk:** Central pontine myelinolysis if rapid sodium changes (maintain stable elevated sodium; do not rapidly correct back to normal)

cornerstone-of-pcnsl-treatment-first-lin.notes: 3.5 g/m2 IV over 4 hours; aggressive IV hydration (2-3 L/m2) starting 12h before and continuing 48h after; urine alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (target pH >7.0); leucovorin rescue starting 24h after MTX completion (25 mg IV/PO q6h until MTX level <0.05 micromol/L); q2 week cycles x 5-7 based on response; hold TMP-SMX during MTX weeks

ongoing: Serum MTX levels at 24h, 48h, 72h (and until <0.05 micromol/L)
creatinine q12h during infusion and for 72h after

adjust insulin as steroid dose changes

glycemic-control-during-donor-management.notes: Regular insulin infusion; target blood glucose 120-180 mg/dL; start if BG >150 mg/dL; titrate per institutional insulin drip protocol; avoid hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL)

glycemic-control-to-reduce-icuaw-risk-an.indication: Glycemic control to reduce ICUAW risk and severity; hyperglycemia is major modifiable risk factor
glycemic-control-to-reduce-icuaw-risk-an.notes: Insulin infusion per ICU protocol; target glucose 140-180 mg/dL (NICE-SUGAR target); avoid hypoglycemia <70 mg/dL; transition to subcutaneous when tolerating enteral nutrition

doseOptions.orderSentence: Insulin sliding scale Per protocol SC

steroid-induced-hyperglycemia-management.notes: Per sliding scale if glucose >180 mg/dL; adjust per glucose trends

doseOptions.orderSentence: Insulin sliding scale (steroid-induced hyperglycemia) Per protocol SC

glucose-management-during-high-dose-ster.notes: Per institutional sliding scale protocol if glucose >180 mg/dL

doseOptions.orderSentence: Insulin sliding scale Per protocol SC

steroid-induced-hyperglycemia-management.indication: Steroid-induced hyperglycemia management; high-dose methylprednisolone frequently causes glucose >200 mg/dL

doseOptions.orderSentence: Insulin sliding scale Per institutional protocol SC

steroid-induced-hyperglycemia-management.notes: Per protocol if glucose >180 mg/dL; anticipate need on days 2-5 of pulse steroids

ongoing: Glucose q6h minimum during pulse steroids

intensive-medical-therapy-alone.name: Intensive medical therapy alone (for asymptomatic stenosis)

preferred-initial-management-for-most-as.indication: Preferred initial management for most asymptomatic carotid stenosis given contemporary medical therapy effectiveness; annual stroke risk <1% with optimal medical therapy in modern era (vs 2%/year in ACAS era); CREST-2 comparing revascularization + medical vs medical alone

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intensive medical therapy alone (for asymptomatic stenosis) Aspirin 81 mg + statin + antihypertensive PO

preferred-initial-management-for-most-as.notes: Aspirin 81 mg daily + high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40-80 mg or rosuvastatin 20-40 mg) + BP target <140/90; add clopidogrel if high-risk features; aggressive risk factor modification; annual surveillance imaging

contraindications: None (this is baseline management for all patients)

ongoing: progression of stenosis warrants reassessment for intervention

refractory-ocular-and-neurological-behce.indication: Refractory ocular and neurological Behcet's; particularly effective for refractory uveitis with CNS involvement
refractory-ocular-and-neurological-behce.notes: Start 3-6 million IU (MIU) SC three times weekly; increase to 6-9 MIU TIW as needed; taper to lowest effective dose once remission achieved; typically combined with azathioprine; Pre-treatment: CBC, LFTs, TSH, depression screening, ANA

ongoing: CBC q2 weeks initially, then monthly

general.notes: 30 mcg IM weekly
250 mcg SC every other day

severe-progressive-vasoconstriction-with.indication: Severe, progressive vasoconstriction with ischemic deficit refractory to oral/IV therapy — alternative to IA verapamil
severe-progressive-vasoconstriction-with.notes: Nicardipine 5-10 mg intra-arterial per vessel during cerebral angiography

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intra-arterial vasodilator therapy (endovascular rescue) 5-10 mg PO

general.notes: Verapamil 5-10 mg intra-arterial or nicardipine 5-10 mg intra-arterial; via catheter into spastic vessel during angiography. For medically refractory vasospasm

severe-progressive-vasoconstriction-with.indication: Severe, progressive vasoconstriction with ischemic deficit refractory to oral/IV therapy — endovascular rescue
severe-progressive-vasoconstriction-with.notes: Verapamil 5-10 mg intra-arterial per vessel during cerebral angiography; may repeat in multiple territories; performed by neurointerventionalist

acute-migraine-with-aura-rapid-onset-opt.indication: Acute migraine with aura; rapid onset option
acute-migraine-with-aura-rapid-onset-opt.notes: 4% lidocaine 0.5 mL per nostril directed at sphenopalatine fossa; may repeat x1 in 15 min

refractory-coccidioidal-meningitis-not-r.indication: Refractory coccidioidal meningitis not responding to systemic azoles; rarely used due to toxicity; specialist administration only
refractory-coccidioidal-meningitis-not-r.notes: Start 0.01 mg IT; titrate slowly to 0.5 mg as tolerated over weeks; administered via LP or Ommaya reservoir; mix with CSF and inject slowly

refractory-rigidity-and-spasms-not-contr.indication: Refractory rigidity and spasms not controlled by maximal oral medications; severe functional impairment
refractory-rigidity-and-spasms-not-contr.notes: Trial: 50-100 mcg intrathecal bolus; if positive response, implant programmable pump; typical maintenance 100-800 mcg/day continuous infusion; titrate over weeks

contraindications: patient unable to return for pump refills

ongoing: withdrawal symptoms if pump malfunction (medical emergency -- similar to status spasticus)

severe-generalized-dystonia-with-spastic.indication: Severe generalized dystonia with spasticity component; CP-related
severe-generalized-dystonia-with-spastic.notes: Test dose 25-100 mcg; maintenance typically 100-1000 mcg/day; titrate over months

severe-spasticity-refractory-to-maximum-.indication: Severe spasticity refractory to maximum oral medications; intolerable side effects from oral antispasticity agents
severe-spasticity-refractory-to-maximum-.notes: Trial with intrathecal bolus 50-100 mcg; if >50% spasticity reduction, proceed to pump implantation; maintenance 100-900 mcg/day

contraindications: inability to follow up for pump refills

ongoing: withdrawal syndrome if pump malfunction (fever, seizures, rhabdomyolysis — EMERGENCY)

alternative-or-second-line-it-agent-sust.indication: Alternative or second-line IT agent; sustained-release formulation allows less frequent dosing; solid tumors and hematologic malignancies
alternative-or-second-line-it-agent-sust.notes: 50 mg liposomal cytarabine (DepoCyt) IT via Ommaya or LP q2 weeks for 5 doses (induction), then q4 weeks (maintenance); co-administer dexamethasone 4 mg PO BID for 5 days starting day of injection (prevents chemical arachnoiditis); NOTE: DepoCyt supply has been intermittent — verify availability

ongoing: neurologic exam (chemical arachnoiditis occurs in 20-40% without dex prophylaxis)

first-line-it-chemotherapy-for-lmd-from-.indication: First-line IT chemotherapy for LMD from solid tumors (breast, lung); best evidence base among IT agents
first-line-it-chemotherapy-for-lmd-from-.notes: 12 mg in 3-5 mL preservative-free normal saline via Ommaya reservoir; twice weekly for 4 weeks (induction), then weekly for 4 weeks (consolidation), then monthly (maintenance); co-administer leucovorin 10 mg PO q6h x 4 doses starting 24h after each IT dose to prevent systemic toxicity

it-chemotherapy-when-ommaya-reservoir-no.indication: IT chemotherapy when Ommaya reservoir not yet placed; initial treatment while awaiting surgery
it-chemotherapy-when-ommaya-reservoir-no.notes: 12 mg in 3-5 mL preservative-free normal saline injected slowly via LP; patient lies flat for 1 hour post-injection; same schedule as Ommaya administration; Ommaya preferred for repeated dosing (avoids repeat LPs, more reliable CSF distribution)

positive-csf-cytology-flow-cytometry-lep.indication: Positive CSF cytology/flow cytometry; leptomeningeal involvement documented; administered via lumbar puncture or Ommaya reservoir; role diminished with HD-MTX (which achieves therapeutic CSF levels)
positive-csf-cytology-flow-cytometry-lep.notes: 12 mg IT (preservative-free) via LP or Ommaya reservoir; 2x/week for 4 weeks, then weekly x4-8 weeks, then monthly; reconstitute in preservative-free normal saline; give with leucovorin 10 mg PO q6h x 4 doses starting 24h after IT MTX

contraindications: Opening pressure before each IT injection
blocked CSF flow (perform flow study first — blocked flow increases neurotoxicity)

ongoing: MRI q6-8 weeks for response and leukoencephalopathy surveillance

severe-refractory-sih-as-bridge-to-defin.indication: Severe refractory SIH as bridge to definitive repair; restores CSF volume temporarily

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intrathecal saline infusion NS at 15-30 mL/hr Intrathecal

severe-refractory-sih-as-bridge-to-defin.notes: Intrathecal normal saline via lumbar drain at 15-30 mL/hr; temporary measure only; risk of infection increases with duration

ongoing: Infection surveillance, neurologic exam, ICP monitoring

third-line-it-agent-used-when-methotrexa.indication: Third-line IT agent; used when methotrexate and cytarabine not tolerated or disease refractory; breast cancer LMD
third-line-it-agent-used-when-methotrexa.notes: 10 mg in 3-5 mL preservative-free normal saline via Ommaya reservoir; twice weekly during induction; taper to weekly then monthly per response

ongoing: CBC (myelosuppression more common than with MTX)

respiratory-failure-not-responding-to-ni.indication: Respiratory failure not responding to NIV
respiratory-failure-not-responding-to-ni.notes: Discuss advance directives; many ALS patients decline invasive ventilation; if desired, standard intubation and ventilation

melanoma-with-leptomeningeal-disease-imm.indication: Melanoma with leptomeningeal disease; immunotherapy combination has best intracranial activity
melanoma-with-leptomeningeal-disease-imm.notes: Ipilimumab 3 mg/kg + nivolumab 1 mg/kg IV q3 weeks for 4 cycles, then nivolumab 480 mg IV q4 weeks maintenance; BRAF+ melanoma: dabrafenib 150 mg BID + trametinib 2 mg daily is alternative (faster response); response rate for LMD is lower than parenchymal disease

contraindications: Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic immunosuppression (relative)
concurrent high-dose steroids (>10 mg prednisone equivalent — reduces immunotherapy efficacy)

ongoing: LFTs and TSH before each cycle
irAE monitoring (hepatic, thyroid, adrenal, colitis, pneumonitis, dermatitis)

iron-deficiency-anemia-correction-anemia.indication: Iron deficiency anemia correction; anemia worsens cerebral ischemia in moyamoya; optimize before surgery

doseOptions.orderSentence: Iron supplementation (if deficient) 325 mg ferrous sulfate daily PO

ongoing: Ferritin, iron studies q3 months until replete

alternative-to-voriconazole-for-cns-aspe.indication: Alternative to voriconazole for CNS aspergillosis; better tolerated; fewer drug interactions; does NOT require cyclodextrin (safe in renal impairment)
alternative-to-voriconazole-for-cns-aspe.notes: Loading: 200 mg IV or PO q8h for 6 doses (48 hours); Maintenance: 200 mg IV or PO daily

first-line-anti-tb-therapy-excellent-cns.indication: First-line anti-TB therapy; excellent CNS penetration (CSF levels 80-90% of serum); bactericidal against M. tuberculosis
first-line-anti-tb-therapy-excellent-cns.notes: 5 mg/kg PO/IV daily (max 300 mg/day); some experts use 10 mg/kg for first 2 months for enhanced CNS penetration; duration 12 months

continuation-phase-anti-tb-therapy-month.indication: Continuation phase anti-TB therapy; months 3-12 of treatment

adenosine-a2a-antagonist-adjunct-for-off.indication: Adenosine A2A antagonist; adjunct for OFF time

Standard tPA exclusions: >4.5h from last known well

ibm-related-dysphagia-unresponsive-to-co.notes: 2 g/kg total divided over 2-5 days (e.g., 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days) every 4 weeks; assess dysphagia response objectively at 3 and 6 months; discontinue if no improvement

steroid-refractory-attack-second-line-ac.indication: Steroid-refractory attack; second-line acute treatment after IV steroids

alternative-rescue-therapy-when-plex-una.indication: Alternative rescue therapy when PLEX unavailable

acute-lems-exacerbation-with-significant.indication: Acute LEMS exacerbation with significant functional impairment; rapid symptom control; pre-treatment or perioperative optimization

chronic-immunomodulation-for-lems-with-o.notes: 1 g/kg IV every 4 weeks (may adjust to 0.4-1 g/kg based on response); infuse over 4-6 hours

autoimmune-cerebellar-ataxia-anti-gad-pa.indication: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia (anti-GAD); paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration; Miller Fisher syndrome (GBS variant with ataxia); post-infectious cerebellitis
autoimmune-cerebellar-ataxia-anti-gad-pa.notes: 0.4 g/kg/day IV for 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse slowly — start 0.5 mL/kg/h, increase to max 4 mL/kg/h; premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine

first-line-immunotherapy-for-sps-class-i.indication: First-line immunotherapy for SPS; Class I evidence (Dalakas 2001 NEJM RCT); reduces stiffness and improves function
first-line-immunotherapy-for-sps-class-i.notes: 0.4 g/kg/day IV for 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse initial rate 0.5 mL/kg/hr, increase q30min by 0.5 mL/kg/hr to max 4 mL/kg/hr; premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine; repeat every 4-6 weeks for maintenance

first-line-immunotherapy-antibody-mediat.indication: First-line immunotherapy; antibody-mediated mechanism; given concurrently or sequentially with IV steroids
first-line-immunotherapy-antibody-mediat.notes: 0.4 g/kg/day IV x 5 days (total 2 g/kg); infuse per weight-based protocol; premedicate with acetaminophen, diphenhydramine

maintenance-immunotherapy-for-partially-.indication: Maintenance immunotherapy for partially responsive paraneoplastic syndrome; especially cell-surface antibody syndromes
maintenance-immunotherapy-for-partially-.notes: 0.4 g/kg IV every 4 weeks OR 1 g/kg IV every 4-6 weeks; adjust per response

first-line-therapy-in-susac-syndrome-alo.indication: FIRST-LINE therapy in Susac syndrome (along with corticosteroids); anti-endothelial cell antibody neutralization; immunomodulation; start early and aggressively
first-line-therapy-in-susac-syndrome-alo.notes: 0.4 g/kg/day IV x 5 days (total 2 g/kg) for induction; infuse per weight-based protocol; premedicate with acetaminophen 650 mg PO and diphenhydramine 25-50 mg IV/PO; followed by maintenance IVIG (see Section 3D)

severe-refractory-neuralgic-amyotrophy-d.indication: Severe/refractory neuralgic amyotrophy; diabetic amyotrophy (DLRPN) with vasculitic features; atypical inflammatory plexopathy
severe-refractory-neuralgic-amyotrophy-d.notes: 0.4 g/kg/day IV x 5 days (total 2 g/kg); repeat q4 weeks x 3-6 months if responsive

IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk — check IgA level)

maintenance-immunomodulation-following-a.indication: Maintenance immunomodulation following acute induction; backbone of long-term Susac management; prevents relapse and further end-organ damage
maintenance-immunomodulation-following-a.notes: Maintenance: 0.4 g/kg IV monthly OR 2 g/kg IV divided over 2-5 days every 4 weeks; taper to q6-8 weeks after 12-24 months of stability; minimum 2 years of treatment recommended

adjunctive-for-refractory-post-anoxic-se.indication: Adjunctive for refractory post-anoxic seizures; NMDA antagonism addresses late-stage glutamate excitotoxicity

status-migrainosus-refractory-to-dhe.notes: 0.1-0.3 mg/kg/hr continuous infusion for 24-48 hr; subanesthetic dosing only

super-refractory-ncse-nmda-receptor-anta.indication: Super-refractory NCSE; NMDA receptor antagonist (different mechanism); may add to midazolam/propofol
super-refractory-ncse-nmda-receptor-anta.notes: Bolus: 1-3 mg/kg IV; Infusion: 0.5-5 mg/kg/hr; does not require intubation at lower doses

refractory-status-migrainosus-not-respon.indication: Refractory status migrainosus not responding to standard therapies; NMDA receptor antagonism disrupts central sensitization

refractory-status-migrainosus-not-respon.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV bolus, then 0.1-0.5 mg/kg/hr infusion; titrate by 0.1 mg/kg/hr q30min; max 1 mg/kg/hr; typical duration 24-48h

ongoing: 2024 data: combination may reduce SE duration faster than midazolam alone

dre-especially-glut1-deficiency-and-pdc-.indication: DRE, especially GLUT1 deficiency and PDC deficiency (first-line); 50% seizure reduction in ~50% of adults; mechanism involves ketone bodies as alternative fuel
dre-especially-glut1-deficiency-and-pdc-.notes: Initiate under dietitian supervision; 4:1 ratio (4g fat per 1g carb+protein); caloric restriction not required in adults; monitor ketosis with urine/serum ketones; 3-month trial minimum

ongoing: Serum ketones, lipids, CMP q3 months

first-line-nsaid-for-acute-headache-in-e.notes: 30 mg IV push (15 mg if age >65, CrCl <50, or weight <50 kg); max 5 days total NSAID use

moderate-severe-headache-pain-during-wor.notes: 30 mg IV once (15 mg if >65y, CrCl <50, or weight <50 kg); max 2 doses in 24h

nsaid-for-severe-thunderclap-headache-re.indication: NSAID for severe thunderclap headache refractory to acetaminophen; short-course only

severe-acute-tth-in-ed-nsaid-responsive-.indication: Severe acute TTH in ED; NSAID-responsive headache
severe-acute-tth-in-ed-nsaid-responsive-.notes: 30 mg IV x1 (15 mg if >65y, renal impairment, or <50 kg); do not exceed 5 days total NSAIDs

acute-severe-plexopathy-pain-short-term.notes: 30 mg IV/IM q6h; max 5 days; reduce to 15 mg if elderly or renal impairment

first-line-acute-migraine-with-aura-in-e.indication: First-line acute migraine with aura in ED

Renal disease, GI bleeding, anticoagulation, recent bypass surgery

seizure-management-if-seizures-occur-not.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV or PO BID; load 1000-1500 mg if acute seizure; max 3000 mg/day

general.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day. Seizures occur in 40-60% of HSV encephalitis

seizure-management-if-seizures-develop-u.indication: Seizure management if seizures develop (uncommon in uncomplicated viral meningitis; suggests encephalitis component); NOT routine prophylaxis
seizure-management-if-seizures-develop-u.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day

seizures-secondary-to-cortical-or-mening.indication: Seizures secondary to cortical or meningeal neurosarcoidosis
seizures-secondary-to-cortical-or-mening.notes: Start 500 mg BID (IV or PO); increase by 500 mg/day q1-2wk; max 3000 mg/day; transition to PO when tolerated

seizures-neurosyphilis-related-seizures-.indication: Seizures (neurosyphilis-related seizures; meningovascular with cortical involvement)
seizures-neurosyphilis-related-seizures-.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day

aed-loading-after-benzodiazepine-for-sei.indication: AED loading after benzodiazepine for seizure in LMD; preferred AED in cancer (no CYP interactions with chemotherapy or targeted agents)
aed-loading-after-benzodiazepine-for-sei.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV over 15 min; avoid phenytoin/fosphenytoin if possible (CYP interactions with chemotherapy and targeted agents); transition to oral 500-1500 mg BID for maintenance

post-seizure-maintenance-cortical-irrita.indication: Post-seizure maintenance; cortical irritation from leptomeningeal disease; preferred AED in cancer (no CYP interactions with chemotherapy)
post-seizure-maintenance-cortical-irrita.notes: Start 500 mg PO/IV BID; titrate to seizure control (max 1500 mg BID); renal dose adjustment if CrCl <50; IV available if NPO

asm-for-recurrent-seizures-after-mgso4-f.indication: ASM for recurrent seizures after MgSO4 failure; preferred over phenytoin in pregnancy due to better safety profile; for known epilepsy patients needing IV loading
asm-for-recurrent-seizures-after-mgso4-f.notes: Load 1000-1500 mg IV over 15 min; maintenance 500-1000 mg IV/PO q12h; renal dosing if CrCl <50

preferred-asm-in-pregnancy-low-teratogen.indication: Preferred ASM in pregnancy; low teratogenicity; safe in breastfeeding; renal elimination (no hepatic interactions)
preferred-asm-in-pregnancy-low-teratogen.notes: Monitor levels each trimester (decreases ~60%); increase dose to maintain seizure control; renal clearance increases in pregnancy; postpartum dose reduction needed

limited-evidence-case-reports-of-benefit.indication: Limited evidence; case reports of benefit
limited-evidence-case-reports-of-benefit.notes: Start 500 mg BID; titrate to 1500-3000 mg/day; adjust for renal function

anti-seizure-medication-loading-for-new-.indication: Anti-seizure medication loading for new seizures; preferred in CNS lymphoma patients due to no CYP enzyme induction (preserves chemotherapy efficacy)
anti-seizure-medication-loading-for-new-.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load, then 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; renal dosing if GFR <50

seizure-prevention-after-first-seizure-n.indication: Seizure prevention after first seizure; NO prophylactic AEDs in patients without seizures; preferred due to no drug interactions with chemotherapy
seizure-prevention-after-first-seizure-n.notes: Start 500 mg BID; titrate by 500 mg/day q1-2 weeks to seizure control; max 3000 mg/day; renal dosing if GFR <50

anti-seizure-medication-if-seizures-have.indication: Anti-seizure medication if seizures have occurred; prophylaxis if large territory infarction or cortical involvement
anti-seizure-medication-if-seizures-have.notes: Load: 1000-1500 mg IV; Maintenance: 500-1500 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day

acute-symptomatic-seizures-prophylaxis-i.indication: Acute symptomatic seizures; prophylaxis if hemorrhagic infarction or cortical involvement
acute-symptomatic-seizures-prophylaxis-i.notes: Load: 1000-1500 mg IV; Maintenance: 500-1500 mg IV/PO BID (max 3000 mg/day)

seizure-prophylaxis-or-treatment-if-seiz.indication: Seizure prophylaxis or treatment if seizures occur (more common with PRES overlap or cortical SAH)
seizure-prophylaxis-or-treatment-if-seiz.notes: Load 1000-1500 mg IV, then 500-1000 mg BID; adjust for renal function

first-line-antiseizure-medication-for-nc.indication: First-line antiseizure medication for NCC-related seizures; no hepatic enzyme induction (avoids reducing praziquantel levels); seizures occur in 70-90% of parenchymal NCC
first-line-antiseizure-medication-for-nc.notes: 1000 mg IV load, then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; titrate by 500 mg/day every 2 weeks to 1500 mg BID if seizures persist; max 3000 mg/day; does NOT interact with antiparasitic drugs

continue-after-successful-loading-broad-.indication: Continue after successful loading; broad-spectrum maintenance
continue-after-successful-loading-broad-.notes: 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID (max 3000 mg/day); adjust for renal function

seizure-management-in-adem-like-presenta.indication: Seizure management in ADEM-like presentation with cortical involvement
seizure-management-in-adem-like-presenta.notes: Start 500 mg BID; increase by 500 mg/day q1-2wk; max 3000 mg/day

first-line-for-post-anoxic-seizures-and-.indication: First-line for post-anoxic seizures and NCSE (common in 10-30% of comatose post-arrest patients); treat all electrographic seizures aggressively
first-line-for-post-anoxic-seizures-and-.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV BID; transition to PO when able; no hepatic metabolism; minimal drug interactions

post-anoxic-myoclonus-adjunctive-less-ef.indication: Post-anoxic myoclonus (adjunctive; less effective as monotherapy for myoclonus than clonazepam)
post-anoxic-myoclonus-adjunctive-less-ef.notes: Start 500 mg PO BID; titrate to 1000-1500 mg BID

myoclonus-treatment-especially-perm-vari.indication: Myoclonus treatment (especially PERM variant); anti-seizure prophylaxis if cortical involvement
myoclonus-treatment-especially-perm-vari.notes: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase by 500 mg/day q1-2wk; max 3000 mg/day

seizure-management-in-paraneoplastic-lim.indication: Seizure management in paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis; preferred first-line ASM
seizure-management-in-paraneoplastic-lim.notes: Load: 1000-1500 mg IV; Maintenance: 500 mg BID, titrate to 1000-1500 mg BID; max 3000 mg/day

seizure-prophylaxis-and-treatment-in-cjd.indication: Seizure prophylaxis and treatment in CJD; preferred first-line ASM due to minimal drug interactions
seizure-prophylaxis-and-treatment-in-cjd.notes: Load 1000-1500 mg IV; maintenance 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; max 3000 mg/day

myoclonus-alternative-or-adjunct-when-be.indication: Myoclonus -- alternative or adjunct when benzodiazepine sedation is limiting; also provides seizure coverage
myoclonus-alternative-or-adjunct-when-be.notes: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase by 500 mg/day every 1-2 weeks; max 3000 mg/day

broad-spectrum-asm-first-line-for-focal-.indication: Broad-spectrum ASM; first-line for focal and generalized epilepsy; no significant drug interactions; renal elimination
broad-spectrum-asm-first-line-for-focal-.notes: Start 250-500 mg BID; increase by 500 mg/day q1-2wk; target 1000-1500 mg BID; max 3000 mg/day; adjust for renal impairment

anti-seizure-medication-if-seizures-have.indication: Anti-seizure medication if seizures have occurred; prophylaxis if extensive cortical involvement on MRI
anti-seizure-medication-if-seizures-have.notes: Load: 1000-1500 mg IV; Maintenance: 500-1500 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day

post-stroke-seizures-5-10-incidence-high.indication: Post-stroke seizures (5-10% incidence; higher with cortical involvement and hemorrhagic stroke); preferred ASM post-stroke
post-stroke-seizures-5-10-incidence-high.notes: Start 500 mg BID; increase by 500 mg q1-2wk; target 500-1000 mg BID; max 3000 mg/day; no hepatic interactions with stroke medications

seizure-management-if-seizures-occur-not.indication: Seizure management (if seizures occur; NOT routine prophylaxis)
seizure-management-if-seizures-occur-not.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day

seizure-prophylaxis-in-brain-abscess-sei.indication: Seizure prophylaxis in brain abscess (seizure incidence 25-50%); recommended for all supratentorial abscesses, especially frontal and temporal locations
seizure-prophylaxis-in-brain-abscess-sei.notes: 1000 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; titrate to 1500 mg BID if needed; max 3000 mg/day; continue for at least 3-6 months after resolution

only-if-sah-confirmed-or-seizure-occurs-.indication: ONLY if SAH confirmed or seizure occurs; not routine for undifferentiated thunderclap headache
only-if-sah-confirmed-or-seizure-occurs-.notes: 1000 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID. Use short-term (3-7 days) in confirmed SAH per AHA guidelines

anti-seizure-medication-loading-for-new-.indication: Anti-seizure medication loading for new seizures associated with meningioma; preferred due to no CYP enzyme induction and favorable safety profile
anti-seizure-medication-loading-for-new-.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load, then 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; renal dosing if GFR <50

seizure-prevention-after-first-seizure-f.indication: Seizure prevention after first seizure from meningioma; NO prophylactic AEDs in patients without seizures unless high-risk perioperative period
seizure-prevention-after-first-seizure-f.notes: Start 500 mg BID; titrate by 500 mg/day q1-2 weeks to seizure control; max 3000 mg/day; renal dosing if GFR <50

short-course-perioperative-seizure-proph.indication: Short-course perioperative seizure prophylaxis for craniotomy in patients without seizure history; 7-day course only per institutional protocol; NOT recommended beyond 7 days without documented seizure
short-course-perioperative-seizure-proph.notes: Levetiracetam 500 mg BID starting day of surgery; discontinue at 7 days post-operatively unless seizure occurs; if seizure occurs, convert to maintenance dosing

continued-seizure-prophylaxis-if-seizure.indication: Continued seizure prophylaxis if seizures occurred during PRES; typically continue 3-6 months then taper if MRI normalized and EEG normal
continued-seizure-prophylaxis-if-seizure.notes: 500-1000 mg PO BID; dose based on acute loading; may taper at 3-6 months if PRES fully resolved on imaging

seizure-management-seizures-occur-in-20-.indication: Seizure management (seizures occur in 20-30% of TBM); preferred ASM due to minimal hepatic metabolism (important with hepatotoxic RIPE therapy)
seizure-management-seizures-occur-in-20-.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day; preferred over phenytoin because no significant hepatic metabolism or CYP interactions with RIPE

first-line-maintenance.notes: 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; start 500 mg BID, may increase by 500 mg/dose weekly; max 3000 mg/day

precautions: Behavioral/psychiatric adverse events (irritability, aggression, anxiety, depression)

monitoring.frequency: Renal function annually; behavioral assessment at each visit

patientCounseling: Report mood changes, irritability, aggression, depression, or suicidal thoughts immediately
May cause drowsiness - avoid driving until effects known
Do not stop abruptly - may precipitate seizures
Keppra Rage is real - discuss with provider if mood changes
Pyridoxine (B6) may help with irritability

adjunctive-seizure-prophylaxis-not-a-sub.indication: Adjunctive seizure prophylaxis; NOT a substitute for benzodiazepines for withdrawal management; may be considered if concurrent epilepsy diagnosis or concern for non-withdrawal seizures
adjunctive-seizure-prophylaxis-not-a-sub.notes: 1000-1500 mg IV q12h; does NOT treat withdrawal syndrome itself; use as adjunct only

general.notes: 60 mg/kg IV (max 4500 mg) over 10-15 min

second-line-fewest-drug-interactions-ren.indication: Second-line; fewest drug interactions; renal dosing simple
second-line-fewest-drug-interactions-ren.notes: 60 mg/kg IV (max 4500 mg) infused over 15 min; then maintenance 1000-1500 mg IV/PO BID

first-line-acute-loading.notes: 40-60 mg/kg IV (max 4500 mg) over 15 min; OR 1500-3000 mg IV

acute-loading-if-stable.notes: 1500-3000 mg PO Ã— 1, then start maintenance

dopa-responsive-dystonia-drd-diagnostic-.indication: Dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD); diagnostic trial for young-onset
dopa-responsive-dystonia-drd-diagnostic-.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID; if DRD, dramatic response at low dose; may titrate to 50/200 mg TID; response confirms diagnosis

trial-if-dip-fails-to-resolve-after-drug.indication: Trial if DIP fails to resolve after drug withdrawal (suggests unmasked idiopathic PD)
trial-if-dip-fails-to-resolve-after-drug.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks; response suggests underlying PD

pd-tremor-confirmed-or-strongly-suspecte.indication: PD tremor confirmed or strongly suspected based on clinical features and/or DaTscan; diagnostic and therapeutic trial
pd-tremor-confirmed-or-strongly-suspecte.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks based on response; robust response supports PD diagnosis

parkinsonism-rigidity-bradykinesia.notes: Start 25/100 mg TID; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks; limited efficacy in WD parkinsonism (response variable)

ongoing: Nausea, orthostatic hypotension, dyskinesia, hallucinations (especially if psychotic history)
response to levodopa is diagnostically supportive of PD

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levodopa-carbidopa intestinal gel (Duopa) Continuous infusion Enteral

severe-motor-fluctuations-4-hours-off-da.notes: Via PEG-J; 16-hour infusion; morning bolus + continuous rate + extra doses

drug-resistant-tb-mdr-tb-rifampin-resist.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB); rifampin-resistant TB detected on GeneXpert; alternative when first-line agents not tolerated; good CNS penetration
drug-resistant-tb-mdr-tb-rifampin-resist.notes: 750-1000 mg PO/IV daily; superior CNS penetration among fluoroquinolones; critical component of MDR-TB regimen

reliable-contraception-for-women-on-enzy.indication: Reliable contraception for women on enzyme-inducing ASMs; NOT affected by enzyme induction (unlike oral contraceptives)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levonorgestrel IUD (Mirena/Liletta) N/A — device placement IUD

reliable-contraception-for-women-on-enzy.notes: Place levonorgestrel IUD for reliable contraception; efficacy NOT reduced by enzyme-inducing ASMs; preferred over oral contraceptives for women on phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital, topiramate >200 mg

hypothyroidism-contributing-to-encephalo.notes: 1.6 mcg/kg/day PO (adjust for age/cardiac status); IV dose is 75% of oral dose if unable to take PO

maintain-euthyroid-state-hypothyroidism-.indication: Maintain euthyroid state; hypothyroidism present in 25-30%
maintain-euthyroid-state-hypothyroidism-.notes: 1.6 mcg/kg/day PO; adjust to keep TSH 0.5-2.5 mIU/L

hormone-replacement-therapy-hrt-for-brai.indication: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for brain-dead donors; pituitary failure causes hypothyroidism; improves hemodynamic stability and organ function
hormone-replacement-therapy-hrt-for-brai.notes: HRSA protocol: 20 mcg IV bolus then 10 mcg/hr continuous infusion; alternative: T3 (liothyronine) 4 mcg IV bolus then 3 mcg/hr; improves cardiac output and donor hemodynamics

central-hypothyroidism-from-hypothalamic.notes: Start 25-50 mcg daily (lower in elderly/cardiac disease); titrate q6-8 weeks by 12.5-25 mcg; target free T4 in upper half of normal range (NOT TSH-guided for central hypothyroidism)

general.notes: Start 25-50 mcg daily; titrate per TSH

hypothyroidism-treatment-in-dm1-patients.indication: Hypothyroidism treatment in DM1 patients with confirmed thyroid dysfunction
hypothyroidism-treatment-in-dm1-patients.notes: Start 25-50 mcg PO daily (lower dose in elderly or cardiac disease); titrate by 12.5-25 mcg q6-8 weeks based on TSH; take on empty stomach 30-60 min before breakfast

ongoing: TSH, free T4 q4-6 weeks until stable, then q3-6 months
monitor for adrenal crisis if cortisol not replaced

localized-paresthesia-pain.notes: Apply 1-3 patches to painful area for 12 hours on, 12 hours off

localized-neuropathic-pain-adjunct-thera.notes: Apply 1-3 patches to painful area for 12 hours on, 12 hours off; max 3 patches simultaneously

general.notes: Up to 3 patches daily; 12h on/12h off

localized-pain-adjunctive-therapy-allody.notes: Apply to most painful area; up to 3 patches for 12h on/12h off

localized-neuropathic-pain.notes: Apply 1-3 patches to painful area for 12 hours on, 12 hours off

localized-neck-or-radicular-pain-adjunct.indication: Localized neck or radicular pain; adjunctive for neuropathic pain
localized-neck-or-radicular-pain-adjunct.notes: Apply up to 3 patches to painful area for 12 hours on, 12 hours off

general.notes: 4% lidocaine 1 mL applied to ipsilateral nostril (head tilted back); can repeat

sodium-channel-blockade-for-refractory-s.indication: Sodium channel blockade for refractory status migrainosus; typically inpatient protocol

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lidocaine IV infusion 1-2 mg/kg bolus IV

sodium-channel-blockade-for-refractory-s.notes: Load 1-2 mg/kg IV over 20 min, then 1-2 mg/min (60-120 mg/hr) infusion x 24-48h

contraindications: Heart block, severe CHF, hepatic failure

ongoing: Continuous cardiac monitoring, lidocaine level q12h (target <5 mcg/mL), neuro checks for toxicity (perioral numbness, tinnitus, seizures)

localized-neuropathic-pain-adjunctive-to.indication: Localized neuropathic pain; adjunctive to systemic agents
localized-neuropathic-pain-adjunctive-to.notes: Apply up to 3 patches to painful area for 12h on/12h off

localized-radicular-pain.notes: Apply 1-3 patches to affected area for 12h on, 12h off

localized-plexopathy-pain-shoulder-hip-r.notes: Apply 1-3 patches to affected area for 12h on, 12h off

mrsa-brain-abscess-alternative-to-vancom.indication: MRSA brain abscess alternative to vancomycin; excellent CNS penetration; useful when vancomycin levels difficult to maintain
mrsa-brain-abscess-alternative-to-vancom.notes: 600 mg IV/PO q12h; 100% oral bioavailability; duration limited to 4 weeks ideally due to toxicity (use vancomycin for remainder)

drug-resistant-tb-mdr-xdr-tb-excellent-c.indication: Drug-resistant TB (MDR/XDR-TB); excellent CNS penetration; reserve for resistant cases due to toxicity
drug-resistant-tb-mdr-xdr-tb-excellent-c.notes: 600 mg PO/IV daily (some protocols use 600 mg BID initially then reduce to daily); duration limited by toxicity (aim for <6 months if possible)

ongoing: optic neuritis (rare but serious with prolonged use >28 days)

blood-pressure-control-target-130-80-for.indication: Blood pressure control; target <130/80 for secondary prevention
blood-pressure-control-target-130-80-for.notes: Start 5-10 mg daily; titrate to goal BP <130/80; max 40 mg daily

hypertension-target-bp-130-80-for-vascul.indication: Hypertension; target BP <130/80 for vascular protection
hypertension-target-bp-130-80-for-vascul.notes: Start 5-10 mg daily; titrate q2wk to BP goal

blood-pressure-management-for-secondary-.indication: Blood pressure management for secondary stroke prevention; target BP <130/80 after acute phase
blood-pressure-management-for-secondary-.notes: Start 5-10 mg PO daily; titrate to 20-40 mg daily; target BP <130/80

general.notes: Start 5-10 mg PO daily; titrate to 20-40 mg daily; target BP <130/80 after acute phase

first-line-ace-inhibitor-for-post-stroke.indication: First-line ACE inhibitor for post-stroke BP management; target BP <130/80 (SPRINT-like targets for secondary prevention)
first-line-ace-inhibitor-for-post-stroke.notes: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg q1-2wk; target BP <130/80; max 40 mg

first-line-ace-inhibitor-for-bp-manageme.indication: First-line ACE inhibitor for BP management; target BP <130/80 for symptomatic carotid stenosis (secondary stroke prevention); use caution with severe bilateral carotid stenosis (cerebral perfusion risk if BP drops too low)
first-line-ace-inhibitor-for-bp-manageme.notes: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg q1-2wk; target BP <130/80 for symptomatic; <140/90 for asymptomatic (avoid aggressive lowering if bilateral severe stenosis); max 40 mg

contraindications: Cr and K+ at 1-2 weeks after initiation
critical bilateral carotid stenosis with hemodynamic compromise (cautious titration)

ongoing: BMP within 2 weeks of starting (creatinine, potassium)

general.notes: Start 300 mg BID-TID; target serum level 0.6-1.0 mEq/L; usual dose 600-1200 mg/day

downbeat-nystagmus-and-cerebellar-toxici.indication: Downbeat nystagmus and cerebellar toxicity; may be irreversible ("SILENT syndrome" — syndrome of irreversible lithium-effectuated neurotoxicity)
downbeat-nystagmus-and-cerebellar-toxici.notes: Lithium level STAT if nystagmus develops in lithium-treated patient; irreversible cerebellar damage possible

contraindications: Renal impairment, thyroid disease, dehydration, sodium depletion

ongoing: Lithium level, renal function, TSH q3-6 months
nystagmus in lithium-treated patient — STAT level

lithium-toxicity-causing-cerebellar-atax.indication: Lithium toxicity causing cerebellar ataxia; supratherapeutic level

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lithium dose adjustment or discontinuation N/A PO

lithium-toxicity-causing-cerebellar-atax.notes: Hold lithium; aggressive IV hydration; recheck level q6-12h; hemodialysis if level >4.0 or severe symptoms; resume at lower dose when level therapeutic

general.notes: **Phenytoin/Fosphenytoin:** 15-20 mg PE/kg IV (if level very low); **Valproate:** 20-30 mg/kg IV (if level very low); **Levetiracetam:** 1000-1500 mg IV (if not on levetiracetam — can be added); **Note:** Loading the same drug patient is already taking risks toxicity → use cautiously

ongoing: For significantly subtherapeutic levels or if need rapid therapeutic concentration

recurrent-glioblastoma-alkylating-agent-.indication: Recurrent glioblastoma; alkylating agent; can be combined with bevacizumab; single agent option for recurrence
recurrent-glioblastoma-alkylating-agent-.notes: 110 mg/m2 PO as single dose every 6 weeks; reduce to 100 mg/m2 if prior myelosuppression; take on empty stomach; do not repeat until platelets >100K and WBC >4K

ongoing: CBC with differential weekly for 6 weeks after each dose (nadir at 4-6 weeks)

ototoxic-especially-iv-high-dose-or-in-r.indication: Ototoxic, especially IV high-dose or in renal impairment; usually reversible
ototoxic-especially-iv-high-dose-or-in-r.notes: Use lowest effective dose; avoid rapid IV bolus; ethacrynic acid more ototoxic than furosemide

contraindications: Pre-existing hearing loss with high doses (relative)

severe-chorea-causing-injury-or-exhausti.indication: Severe chorea causing injury or exhaustion
severe-chorea-causing-injury-or-exhausti.notes: 0.5-2 mg IV/PO q4-6h PRN; short-term use only

status-dystonicus-severe-dystonic-storm.notes: 1-2 mg IV slow push or 2-4 mg PO; may repeat q4-6h PRN; monitor respiratory status

seizure-secondary-to-cortical-parenchyma.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV push (max 4 mg/dose); repeat x1 in 5 minutes if seizure persists

acute-seizure-termination-20-40-of-gbm-p.indication: Acute seizure termination; 20-40% of GBM patients present with seizures
acute-seizure-termination-20-40-of-gbm-p.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

anxiety-dyspnea-end-of-life.notes: 0.5-1 mg PO/SL q8h PRN for anxiety or dyspnea; use low doses due to respiratory depression risk

acute-prolonged-seizure-or-cluster-in-ed.indication: Acute prolonged seizure or cluster in ED/hospital setting
acute-prolonged-seizure-or-cluster-in-ed.notes: 4 mg IV push over 2 min; may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg; prepare for airway management

acute-anxiety-seizure-cluster-prophylaxi.indication: Acute anxiety; seizure cluster prophylaxis during high-risk periods (illness, sleep deprivation)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lorazepam (short-term oral) 0.5 mg q8h PRN PO
Lorazepam (short-term oral) 1 mg q8h PRN PO

acute-anxiety-seizure-cluster-prophylaxi.notes: 0.5-1 mg PO q8h PRN for anxiety or cluster prophylaxis; limit to 2-4 weeks; chronic use increases tolerance and complicates epilepsy management

active-seizure.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); repeat x1 in 5 minutes if seizure persists

acute-agitation-anxiety-insomnia-cataton.indication: Acute agitation, anxiety, insomnia; catatonia features
acute-agitation-anxiety-insomnia-cataton.notes: 1-2 mg IV/PO q4-6h PRN; for catatonia: escalate to 8-24 mg/day as needed

general.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); repeat x1 in 5 min if needed

active-seizure-rescue-rare-in-isolated-v.indication: Active seizure rescue; rare in isolated viral meningitis; more common if encephalitis component
active-seizure-rescue-rare-in-isolated-v.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); may repeat x1 in 5 min

seizure-secondary-to-cortical-meningeal-.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV push (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 minutes

active-seizure-rescue.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); may repeat x1 in 5 min

active-seizures-in-setting-of-leptomenin.indication: Active seizures in setting of leptomeningeal disease with cortical irritation
active-seizures-in-setting-of-leptomenin.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV push (max 4 mg per dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total; bridge to AED loading

second-line-for-eclamptic-seizure-not-re.indication: Second-line for eclamptic seizure not responding to MgSO4; or while MgSO4 loading in progress
second-line-for-eclamptic-seizure-not-re.notes: 4 mg IV push over 2 min; may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg; benzodiazepines cross placenta — anticipate neonatal sedation

acute-seizure-termination-10-20-of-pcnsl.indication: Acute seizure termination; 10-20% of PCNSL patients present with seizures
acute-seizure-termination-10-20-of-pcnsl.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

acute-seizure-management-seizures-occur-.indication: Acute seizure management; seizures occur in 10-25% of PACNS patients

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lorazepam (acute seizure) 0.1 mg/kg IV push IV

acute-seizure-management-seizures-occur-.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 minutes; max 8 mg total

anxiolysis-and-headache-relief-reduces-s.indication: Anxiolysis and headache relief; reduces sympathetic drive which may worsen vasoconstriction
anxiolysis-and-headache-relief-reduces-s.notes: 0.5-1 mg IV/PO q6-8h PRN severe headache or anxiety; short-course only (3-5 days)

active-seizure-in-ncc-breakthrough-seizu.indication: Active seizure in NCC; breakthrough seizure during antiparasitic treatment
active-seizure-in-ncc-breakthrough-seizu.notes: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) over 2 min; repeat x1 in 5 min if seizure continues; max 8 mg total

severe-acute-tremor-causing-significant-.indication: Severe acute tremor causing significant distress or functional impairment; short-term bridge while definitive evaluation underway
