bp-reduction-only-if-hemorrhagic-present.notes: Start 5 mg/h; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; target SBP 140-160 for hemorrhagic moyamoya; AVOID dropping below 140

perioperative-bp-control-for-cea-cas-pre.indication: Perioperative BP control for CEA/CAS; prevent hyperperfusion syndrome; maintain BP 100-150 systolic post-CEA; rapid onset and easy titration
perioperative-bp-control-for-cea-cas-pre.notes: Start 5 mg/hr IV infusion; titrate by 2.5 mg/hr every 5-15 minutes; target SBP 100-150 (post-CEA) or per surgeon guidance; max 15 mg/hr; transition to oral antihypertensives when stable

refractory-severe-hypertension-not-contr.indication: Refractory severe hypertension not controlled by labetalol + hydralazine; ICU setting

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nicardipine infusion 5 mg/h titrated to 15 mg/h IV

refractory-severe-hypertension-not-contr.notes: Start 5 mg/h IV; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h; target SBP 140-155; reduce BP no more than 25% in first hour

continuous-bp-control-in-acute-dissectio.indication: Continuous BP control in acute dissection with stroke or severe hypertension
continuous-bp-control-in-acute-dissectio.notes: 5 mg/h IV infusion; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h

hypertensive-emergency-sbp-180-sah-with-.indication: Hypertensive emergency (SBP >180); SAH with SBP >160; hypertensive crisis with thunderclap
hypertensive-emergency-sbp-180-sah-with-.notes: 5 mg/h IV; titrate by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h. Target SBP <160 if SAH suspected (until aneurysm secured). For hypertensive emergency: reduce MAP by 20-25% in first hour

treatment-of-intestinal-taenia-solium-ta.indication: Treatment of intestinal Taenia solium (taeniasis) to eliminate tapeworm and prevent ongoing autoinfection and community transmission
treatment-of-intestinal-taenia-solium-ta.notes: 2 g PO as single dose (chew thoroughly then swallow with water); take on empty stomach; purge 2h after to expel worm segments

ongoing: Stool follow-up at 1 and 3 months post-treatment to confirm eradication

oral-antihypertensive-for-severe-hyperte.indication: Oral antihypertensive for severe hypertension when IV access delayed or as transition from IV therapy
oral-antihypertensive-for-severe-hyperte.notes: 10-20 mg PO; may repeat in 30 min if needed; max 30 mg in acute setting; transition to extended-release 30-60 mg daily

contraindications: Concurrent MgSO4 (theoretical concern for potentiated hypotension — monitor closely but combination is used)

ongoing: BP q15 min after first dose

oral-antihypertensive-maintenance-for-pr.indication: Oral antihypertensive maintenance for preeclampsia; calcium channel blocker safe in pregnancy
oral-antihypertensive-maintenance-for-pr.notes: Start 30 mg daily; increase by 30 mg q3-7d; max 120 mg/day; swallow whole, do not crush

suspected-sah-with-vasospasm-rcvs.notes: 60 mg PO q4h x 21 days; reduce to 30 mg q4h if hypotension

calcium-channel-blocker-with-preferentia.indication: Calcium channel blocker with preferential cerebral vascular selectivity; alternative to verapamil
calcium-channel-blocker-with-preferentia.notes: 60 mg PO q4h (or 30 mg q2h if hypotension); continue for 4-12 weeks until imaging resolution; do NOT give IV (severe hypotension)

persistent-thunderclap-headaches-or-wors.indication: Persistent thunderclap headaches or worsening vasoconstriction on standard dose
persistent-thunderclap-headaches-or-wors.notes: Increase from 60 mg to 90 mg PO q4h; monitor BP closely; max 540 mg/day; higher doses increase hypotension risk

alternative-to-verapamil-for-ongoing-ccb.indication: Alternative to verapamil for ongoing CCB therapy during recovery phase
alternative-to-verapamil-for-ongoing-ccb.notes: Continue 60 mg PO q4h for 8-12 weeks; taper by reducing frequency to q6h then q8h over 2-4 weeks once imaging confirms resolution

general.notes: 30 mg TID; limited evidence

cochlear-and-retinal-vasodilation-calciu.indication: Cochlear and retinal vasodilation; calcium channel blocker improves microvascular perfusion; used empirically in Susac protocols for cochlear and retinal ischemia
cochlear-and-retinal-vasodilation-calciu.notes: 30 mg PO q8h; titrate based on blood pressure tolerance; increase to 60 mg q8h if tolerated

sah-confirmed-vasospasm-prevention-corne.notes: 60 mg PO/NG q4h x 21 days. START within 96h of SAH. If hypotension: 30 mg q2h. Do NOT give IV — oral only

rcvs-empiric-calcium-channel-blocker-off.indication: RCVS — empiric calcium channel blocker; off-label but widely used
rcvs-empiric-calcium-channel-blocker-off.notes: 60 mg PO q4h; duration 4-12 weeks until vasoconstriction resolves on follow-up imaging

contraindications: do NOT give IV (severe hypotension risk)

ongoing: Blood pressure q1h initially, then q4h
may cause hypotension especially in first 24-48h

acute-respiratory-failure.notes: IPAP 12-20 cmH2O, EPAP 5-8 cmH2O; FiO2 to maintain SpO2 >92%; close monitoring for escalation

ongoing: ABG, respiratory rate, work of breathing

vasopressor-for-hemodynamic-support-neur.indication: Vasopressor for hemodynamic support; neurogenic shock (loss of sympathetic tone) common in brain death; maintain MAP ≥60 mmHg for valid examination
vasopressor-for-hemodynamic-support-neur.notes: Start 0.05-0.1 mcg/kg/min; titrate to MAP ≥60 mmHg (or ≥70 for donor management); max 0.5 mcg/kg/min; consider adding vasopressin if escalating

second-line-vasopressor-if-vasopressin-i.indication: Second-line vasopressor if vasopressin insufficient; maintain MAP ≥60 mmHg; minimize dose to reduce end-organ catecholamine toxicity
second-line-vasopressor-if-vasopressin-i.notes: Start 0.05 mcg/kg/min; titrate to MAP ≥60; goal: minimize catecholamine use (excess catecholamines damage transplantable organs, especially heart); transition to vasopressin-dominant regimen

post-arrest-myocardial-dysfunction-with-.indication: Post-arrest myocardial dysfunction with MAP <65 mmHg; first-line vasopressor for post-arrest shock
post-arrest-myocardial-dysfunction-with-.notes: Start 0.05-0.1 mcg/kg/min; titrate to MAP >65 (or >80 if signs of cerebral hypoperfusion); max 2 mcg/kg/min

general.notes: 0.1-0.5 mcg/kg/min IV; titrate to MAP >65

contraindications: Peripheral ischemia risk at high doses

ongoing: limit escalation if possible for donor management
try to wean as vasopressin and HRT take effect

critical-maintain-euvolemia-dehydration-.indication: **CRITICAL: Maintain euvolemia**; dehydration is major trigger for ischemic events in moyamoya; aggressive hydration during acute presentation
critical-maintain-euvolemia-dehydration-.notes: 125-250 mL/h isotonic crystalloid; maintain euvolemia; target urine output >0.5 mL/kg/h; AVOID hypovolemia (reduces perfusion through collaterals)

volume-resuscitation-for-orthostatic-hyp.indication: Volume resuscitation for orthostatic hypotension from autonomic dysfunction
volume-resuscitation-for-orthostatic-hyp.notes: 500-1000 mL NS bolus then 75-125 mL/hr maintenance as needed for orthostatic symptoms

rehydration-prolonged-vomiting-and-poor-.indication: Rehydration; prolonged vomiting and poor oral intake common in status migrainosus

doseOptions.orderSentence: Normal saline IV 1000 mL bolus IV

rehydration-prolonged-vomiting-and-poor-.notes: NS 1L bolus over 1-2h, then 75-125 mL/hr maintenance

nephroprotection-during-amphotericin-b-t.indication: Nephroprotection during amphotericin B therapy; prevents amphotericin-induced renal vasoconstriction
nephroprotection-during-amphotericin-b-t.notes: 500-1000 mL IV normal saline infused before each amphotericin B dose

neuropathic-pain-second-line-better-tole.notes: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

neuropathic-pain-second-line-fewer-antic.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line); fewer anticholinergic effects than amitriptyline
neuropathic-pain-second-line-fewer-antic.notes: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

tinnitus-with-comorbid-depression-altern.indication: Tinnitus with comorbid depression; alternative to amitriptyline with fewer anticholinergic effects
tinnitus-with-comorbid-depression-altern.notes: Start 25 mg QHS, titrate to 50-75 mg; less sedating than amitriptyline

general.notes: 10-25 mg QHS; titrate to 75 mg QHS

tca-with-less-sedation-and-anticholinerg.indication: TCA with less sedation and anticholinergic effects than amitriptyline
tca-with-less-sedation-and-anticholinerg.notes: Start 10-25 mg qHS; titrate by 10-25 mg q1-2wk; typical 25-75 mg qHS

alternative-tca-for-post-traumatic-heada.indication: Alternative TCA for post-traumatic headache (fewer anticholinergic effects)
alternative-tca-for-post-traumatic-heada.notes: Start 10 mg PO QHS; increase by 10 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 25-75 mg QHS; max 150 mg

neuropathic-pain-second-line.notes: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

neuropathic-pain-second-line-less-sedati.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line, less sedating than amitriptyline)
neuropathic-pain-second-line-less-sedati.notes: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

prevention-if-amitriptyline-not-tolerate.indication: Prevention if amitriptyline not tolerated (less sedating); chronic TTH
prevention-if-amitriptyline-not-tolerate.notes: Start 10 mg qHS; titrate by 10-25 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 25-75 mg qHS; max 150 mg qHS

neuropathic-pain-second-line-less-sedati.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line; less sedating than amitriptyline)
neuropathic-pain-second-line-less-sedati.notes: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

contraindications: Cardiac arrhythmia, glaucoma, urinary retention, recent MI

ongoing: ECG at baseline if dose >75 mg
ECG if dose >100 mg/day or cardiac risk factors
Sedation (less than amitriptyline), dry mouth, weight gain, constipation
[Sullivan et al. (1993)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8215728/): RCT showed nortriptyline reduced tinnitus loudness and depression scores

acute-symptom-relief-limited-evidence-fo.indication: Acute symptom relief; limited evidence for CTS-specific benefit
acute-symptom-relief-limited-evidence-fo.notes: Ibuprofen 400 mg TID or Naproxen 500 mg BID; short course (7-14 days); take with food; not for long-term use

nsaids-reduce-renal-clearance-of-methotr.indication: NSAIDs reduce renal clearance of methotrexate, increasing systemic toxicity risk even with IT administration
nsaids-reduce-renal-clearance-of-methotr.notes: Avoid ibuprofen, naproxen, ketorolac while receiving IT or systemic methotrexate; use acetaminophen for pain

contraindications: Concurrent IT or systemic methotrexate use

refractory-headache-occipital-predominan.indication: Refractory headache; occipital-predominant pain; avoids systemic medications
refractory-headache-occipital-predominan.notes: 2-3 mL 2% lidocaine (or 0.25% bupivacaine) with or without 40 mg triamcinolone at greater occipital nerve bilaterally

refractory-post-traumatic-headache-occip.notes: 2-3 mL per side with or without methylprednisolone 40 mg

refractory-migraine-occipital-predominan.notes: Inject bupivacaine 0.5% 2-3 mL + triamcinolone 40 mg at greater occipital nerve bilaterally; may add lesser occipital, supraorbital

contraindications: Local anesthetic allergy, infection at site

doseOptions.orderSentence: Occipital nerve block - lidocaine (CPT 64405) 2-3 mL SC

non-systemic-option-safe-in-pregnancy.notes: 2% lidocaine 2-3 mL per side at greater occipital nerve

general.notes: 300 mg IV × 2 doses (2 weeks apart), then 600 mg IV q6 months

ongoing: infusion reactions (premedicate with methylprednisolone, antihistamine, acetaminophen)

refractory-postprandial-hypotension-soma.notes: Start 25 mcg SC 30 min before meals; increase to 50 mcg if needed; max 50 mcg TID; reduces splanchnic blood pooling

ongoing: Blood glucose, GI tolerance, gallbladder ultrasound annually if chronic use

general.notes: 100 mcg SC; second-line if triptans contraindicated
20 mg SC weeks 0, 1, 2, then 20 mg SC monthly

acute-agitation-with-psychosis-alternati.indication: Acute agitation with psychosis; alternative to haloperidol
acute-agitation-with-psychosis-alternati.notes: 5-10 mg IM; may repeat in 2 hours; max 30 mg/day

chorea-with-weight-loss-promotes-weight-.indication: Chorea with weight loss; promotes weight gain
chorea-with-weight-loss-promotes-weight-.notes: Start 2.5-5 mg qHS; titrate to effect; typical 5-15 mg/day

moderate-agitation-or-psychosis.notes: 2.5-5 mg PO/IM BID (start low); max 20 mg/day

severe-agitation-when-other-options-fail.indication: Severe agitation when other options fail; IM for acute crisis
severe-agitation-when-other-options-fail.notes: PO: Start 2.5 mg daily; increase slowly; max 10 mg; IM: 2.5-5 mg for acute crisis

general.notes: 2.5-5 mg PO/IM BID (start low); max 20 mg/day

contraindications: Black box: increased mortality in dementia

friedreich-ataxia-fda-approved-nrf2-acti.indication: Friedreich ataxia — FDA-approved Nrf2 activator; first approved therapy for Friedreich ataxia (2023)
friedreich-ataxia-fda-approved-nrf2-acti.notes: 150 mg PO once daily on empty stomach (1 hour before first meal); swallow capsule whole

ongoing: LFTs at baseline, monthly x 3 months, then q3 months

gi-protection-during-high-dose-corticost.indication: GI protection during high-dose corticosteroid therapy
gi-protection-during-high-dose-corticost.notes: 40 mg PO daily during steroid course and oral taper; IV if NPO

doseOptions.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 20-40 mg PO

gi-protection-during-high-dose-corticost.notes: 20-40 mg PO daily while on steroids

gi-protection-during-high-dose-steroid-t.indication: GI protection during high-dose steroid therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 40 mg IV

gi-protection-during-high-dose-steroid-t.notes: 40 mg IV/PO daily during steroid course and taper

gi-protection-while-on-dexamethasone-cri.indication: GI protection while on dexamethasone; critical illness with steroid use
gi-protection-while-on-dexamethasone-cri.notes: Omeprazole 20 mg PO daily or pantoprazole 40 mg IV daily if NPO; continue throughout steroid course

gi-protection-during-high-dose-steroids.notes: 20-40 mg PO daily while on high-dose prednisone; consider tapering off when steroids reduced

prevention-of-steroid-induced-gi-bleedin.indication: Prevention of steroid-induced GI bleeding during high-dose corticosteroid therapy
prevention-of-steroid-induced-gi-bleedin.notes: 40 mg IV or PO daily during high-dose steroid course and subsequent oral taper

gerd-management-in-patients-with-dysphag.indication: GERD management in patients with dysphagia; GI protection if aspirin or NSAID use
gerd-management-in-patients-with-dysphag.notes: 20 mg PO daily; take 30 minutes before breakfast

gi-ulcer-prevention-during-high-dose-ste.indication: GI ulcer prevention during high-dose steroid therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 40 mg PO

gi-ulcer-prevention-during-high-dose-ste.notes: 40 mg PO/IV daily during IV steroid course and oral taper

gi-protection-during-high-dose-steroids-.indication: GI protection during high-dose steroids + aspirin
gi-protection-during-high-dose-steroids-.notes: 40 mg PO/IV daily while on steroids

general.notes: 20-40 mg daily during steroids

stress-ulcer-prevention-during-high-dose.indication: Stress ulcer prevention during high-dose corticosteroids

doseOptions.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 40 mg IV/PO

stress-ulcer-prevention-during-high-dose.notes: 40 mg IV/PO daily during steroid course and taper

gi-protection-during-chelation-therapy.notes: 20 mg PO daily; take 30 min before chelator

contraindications: Long-term use increases C. diff risk
consider C. difficile risk with prolonged PPI use
long-term use concerns (B12, Mg, bone density)

ongoing: consider H. pylori testing if prolonged use

chronic-migraine-with-aura-15-days-month.indication: Chronic migraine with aura (≥15 days/month); failed oral preventives
chronic-migraine-with-aura-15-days-month.notes: 155-195 units across 31-39 injection sites per PREEMPT protocol; repeat q12 weeks; effect may take 2-3 cycles

ongoing: antibody formation if loss of effect

general.notes: 155-195 units IM q12 weeks (if chronic migraine criteria met)

chronic-post-traumatic-headache-15-days-.indication: Chronic post-traumatic headache (>15 days/month for >3 months)
chronic-post-traumatic-headache-15-days-.notes: 155-195 units IM q12 weeks per PREEMPT protocol

focal-post-stroke-spasticity-not-adequat.indication: Focal post-stroke spasticity not adequately controlled with oral agents; upper or lower limb; reduces spasticity and improves function
focal-post-stroke-spasticity-not-adequat.notes: Upper limb: biceps 100-200 units, flexor digitorum 30-50 units per site; lower limb: gastrocnemius 150-300 units; effect onset 1-2 weeks; duration 3-4 months; repeat q3 months

chronic-migraine-only-15-ha-days-month-l.indication: Chronic migraine ONLY (≥15 HA days/month); Level A evidence; FDA-approved for chronic migraine
chronic-migraine-only-15-ha-days-month-l.notes: 155-195 units IM across 31-39 injection sites q12 weeks; PREEMPT protocol: 7 head/neck muscle groups (frontalis, corrugator, procerus, temporalis, occipitalis, cervical paraspinal, trapezius); 5 units per site

sialorrhea-refractory-to-oral-therapy.notes: 30-50 units per parotid, 10-20 units per submandibular; repeat q3-4 months

contraindications: Active infection at injection sites, myasthenia gravis, Lambert-Eaton syndrome, known hypersensitivity to botulinum toxin
Infection at injection sites, myasthenia gravis

ongoing: Injection site pain, neck pain, eyelid ptosis (1-2%)
assess response at 2nd-3rd cycle (minimum 2 cycles before declaring failure)

first-line-for-blepharospasm.notes: 1.25-5 units per site; inject orbicularis oculi at multiple points; total 25-50 units per eye; repeat q12wk

blepharospasm-causing-functional-blindne.indication: Blepharospasm causing functional blindness; involuntary eyelid closure
blepharospasm-causing-functional-blindne.notes: 2.5-5 units per injection site in orbicularis oculi; total 10-30 units per eye; repeat q12 weeks; specialist administration

ongoing: Ptosis, dry eye, excessive tearing, hematoma

first-line-for-cervical-dystonia-tortico.notes: Start 100-200 units divided among affected muscles (SCM, splenius, trapezius, levator scapulae); adjust based on response; max 300 units/session; repeat q12wk

focal-motor-tics-causing-pain-or-disabil.indication: Focal motor tics causing pain or disability (cervical, facial); phonic tics (vocal cord injection)

doseOptions.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - cervical tics (CPT 64616, J0585) 25-100 units IM

focal-motor-tics-causing-pain-or-disabil.notes: Inject affected muscles; cervical tics 25-100 units divided; facial tics 5-25 units per site; repeat q12wk; EMG guidance for small muscles

dystonia-retrocollis-limb-dystonia-causi.indication: Dystonia (retrocollis, limb dystonia) causing pain or functional impairment

doseOptions.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - dystonia Dose varies by muscle IM

dystonia-retrocollis-limb-dystonia-causi.notes: EMG-guided injection; retrocollis: splenius capitis 50-200 units; dose per target muscle; repeat q12 weeks

ongoing: Dysphagia (especially cervical injections), weakness, pain at injection site

disabling-vocal-tics-coprolalia-loud-voc.indication: Disabling vocal tics (coprolalia, loud vocalizations); refractory to systemic therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) - phonic/vocal tics (CPT 64617, J0585) 1.25-2.5 units IM

disabling-vocal-tics-coprolalia-loud-voc.notes: 1.25-2.5 units per vocal cord via EMG-guided injection; repeat q12wk; specialist procedure

sialorrhea-drooling-not-responsive-to-or.indication: Sialorrhea (drooling) not responsive to oral anticholinergics
sialorrhea-drooling-not-responsive-to-or.notes: 30 units per parotid gland; 20 units per submandibular gland; repeat q12 weeks

focal-hand-dystonia-refractory-to-therap.indication: Focal hand dystonia refractory to therapy modification
focal-hand-dystonia-refractory-to-therap.notes: 10-50 units per muscle; EMG guidance required; target FCR, FCU, FDS as needed; repeat q12wk

standard-first-line-for-sclc-in-p-lems-t.indication: Standard first-line for SCLC in P-LEMS; treatment of underlying malignancy is the primary therapy for paraneoplastic LEMS; neurological symptoms often improve with cancer treatment

doseOptions.orderSentence: Oncology-directed chemotherapy (cisplatin/etoposide) Per oncology protocol IV

standard-first-line-for-sclc-in-p-lems-t.notes: Cisplatin 60-80 mg/m2 day 1 + etoposide 100-120 mg/m2 days 1-3 q21d x 4-6 cycles; defer to oncology for specific regimen

nausea-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-chemot.indication: Nausea/vomiting from elevated ICP, chemotherapy, or radiation
nausea-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-chemot.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

non-dopaminergic-antiemetic-substitute-f.indication: Non-dopaminergic antiemetic substitute for acute settings when metoclopramide or prochlorperazine is causative agent
non-dopaminergic-antiemetic-substitute-f.notes: 4-8 mg IV q8h PRN for nausea; max 24 mg/day

nausea-and-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-me.indication: Nausea and vomiting from elevated ICP, medications (flucytosine, azoles), or meningeal irritation
nausea-and-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-me.notes: 4 mg IV or PO q6h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

nausea-and-vomiting-common-with-meningit.indication: Nausea and vomiting (common with meningitis; worsened by meningeal irritation)
nausea-and-vomiting-common-with-meningit.notes: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN; may increase to 8 mg q6h if refractory

anti-emetic-adjunct-caution-in-first-tri.indication: Anti-emetic adjunct; caution in first trimester

anti-emetic-adjunct-for-outpatient-use-c.indication: Anti-emetic adjunct for outpatient use; caution in first trimester

nausea-and-vomiting-vertebral-dissection.indication: Nausea and vomiting (vertebral dissection with posterior circulation symptoms)

nausea-and-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-ch.indication: Nausea and vomiting from elevated ICP, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy
nausea-and-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-ch.notes: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea/vomiting; use around the clock during IT chemotherapy and radiation; dexamethasone itself provides anti-emetic effect

nausea-associated-with-orthostatic-sympt.indication: Nausea associated with orthostatic symptoms and SIH
nausea-associated-with-orthostatic-sympt.notes: 4-8 mg IV or PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

nausea-vomiting-in-eclampsia-severe-pree.indication: Nausea/vomiting in eclampsia/severe preeclampsia; safe in pregnancy
nausea-vomiting-in-eclampsia-severe-pree.notes: 4 mg IV/PO q8h PRN; max 16 mg/day

nausea-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-chemot.indication: Nausea/vomiting from elevated ICP, chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine), or radiation
nausea-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-chemot.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day; give 30 min before chemotherapy

nausea-vomiting-common-in-withdrawal.notes: 4 mg IV q8h PRN; may also use PO/ODT formulation

nausea-vomiting-when-dopamine-antagonist.indication: Nausea/vomiting when dopamine antagonists contraindicated (Parkinson, QTc prolongation)
nausea-vomiting-when-dopamine-antagonist.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO once; may repeat q8h

nausea-and-vomiting-management.notes: 4 mg IV q6-8h PRN; max 16 mg/day

antiemetic-for-nausea-vomiting-associate.indication: Antiemetic for nausea/vomiting associated with thunderclap headache
antiemetic-for-nausea-vomiting-associate.notes: 4 mg IV/PO q6-8h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

nausea-and-vomiting-common-with-elevated.indication: Nausea and vomiting (common with elevated ICP and antiparasitic therapy; albendazole commonly causes nausea)
nausea-and-vomiting-common-with-elevated.notes: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

nausea-and-vomiting-associated-with-acut.indication: Nausea and vomiting associated with acute cerebellar dysfunction and vertigo
nausea-and-vomiting-associated-with-acut.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

general.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h

nausea-vomiting-from-cerebellar-involvem.indication: Nausea/vomiting from cerebellar involvement or brainstem dysfunction
nausea-vomiting-from-cerebellar-involvem.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

nausea-and-vomiting-may-occur-with-brain.indication: Nausea and vomiting -- may occur with brainstem involvement or medication side effects
nausea-and-vomiting-may-occur-with-brain.notes: 4 mg IV q8h PRN; or 4-8 mg PO q8h PRN

nausea-and-vomiting-management-particula.indication: Nausea and vomiting management; particularly during IVIG or plasma exchange
nausea-and-vomiting-management-particula.notes: 4 mg IV q6-8h PRN; max 16 mg/day

nausea-and-vomiting-associated-with-acut.indication: Nausea and vomiting associated with acute vestibular nystagmus; antiemetic without vestibular suppressant effect
nausea-and-vomiting-associated-with-acut.notes: **Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV or PO q8h PRN for nausea**

nausea-and-vomiting-common-with-elevated.notes: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

nausea-vomiting-common-with-thunderclap-.indication: Nausea/vomiting (common with thunderclap headache and elevated ICP)

nausea-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-or-per.indication: Nausea/vomiting from elevated ICP or perioperative
nausea-vomiting-from-elevated-icp-or-per.notes: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day

nystagmus-is-dose-dependent-toxicity-sig.indication: Nystagmus is dose-dependent toxicity sign; gaze-evoked nystagmus appears before ataxia; monitor levels
nystagmus-is-dose-dependent-toxicity-sig.notes: Free phenytoin level; nystagmus = early toxicity warning; reduce dose immediately if nystagmus develops

second-line-for-myotonia-if-mexiletine-a.indication: Second-line for myotonia if mexiletine and carbamazepine not tolerated; sodium channel blocker with antimyotonic properties
second-line-for-myotonia-if-mexiletine-a.notes: Start 100 mg PO TID; adjust based on levels; target level 10-20 mcg/mL; extended-release: 200-300 mg daily

focal-or-generalized.notes: 300-400 mg daily (extended release) or divided TID (immediate release); adjust by level

contraindications: **TERATOGENIC** (fetal hydantoin syndrome) — use only if no alternative
cardiac conduction disease in DM1 (use with extreme caution)

ongoing: nystagmus is early warning sign of toxicity

phenytoin-toxicity-causing-cerebellar-at.indication: Phenytoin toxicity causing cerebellar ataxia (most common drug-induced cause); supratherapeutic level

doseOptions.orderSentence: Phenytoin dose adjustment or discontinuation N/A IV/PO

phenytoin-toxicity-causing-cerebellar-at.notes: Hold phenytoin; recheck level in 24-48h; resume at lower dose or switch to alternative AED; chronic toxicity may cause permanent cerebellar damage

contraindications: Do not abruptly discontinue if on for seizures — taper and bridge

ongoing: Repeat phenytoin level q12-24h until therapeutic
monitor for seizure breakthrough if reducing dose

acute-seizure-control-if-first-line-agen.indication: Acute seizure control if first-line agents insufficient
acute-seizure-control-if-first-line-agen.notes: Fosphenytoin: 20 mg PE/kg IV (max rate 150 mg PE/min); Maintenance: 5-7 mg/kg/day divided BID-TID (target level 10-20 mcg/mL)

refractory-seizures-second-line-after-le.notes: Fosphenytoin 20 mg PE/kg IV at 150 mg PE/min; maintenance 100 mg PE q8h; target level 10-20 µg/mL

general.notes: Fosphenytoin: 20 mg PE/kg IV (max rate 150 mg PE/min); Maintenance: 5-7 mg/kg/day divided BID-TID (target level 10-20 mcg/mL)
20 mg/kg IV at max 50 mg/min (if fosphenytoin unavailable)

ongoing: MUST use large vein, tissue necrosis risk
give via large vein (tissue necrosis risk)

general.notes: If low (refeeding); K-Phos or Na-Phos IV/PO

hypophosphatemia-correction-common-in-al.indication: Hypophosphatemia correction; common in alcoholism and refeeding

doseOptions.orderSentence: Phosphorus replacement 15-45 mmol IV or 250 mg PO IV/PO

hypophosphatemia-correction-common-in-al.notes: Mild (2.0-2.5): K-Phos 250 mg PO TID; Moderate (1.0-2.0): NaPhos 15-30 mmol IV over 4-6h; Severe (<1.0): 30-45 mmol IV over 6h

general.notes: If prolonged IV antibiotics planned (6-8 weeks); enables outpatient IV therapy (OPAT); placed once stabilized and duration confirmed; confirm tip position with X-ray

visual-hallucinations-and-psychosis.notes: 34 mg once daily; takes 4-6 weeks for effect; no titration; selective 5-HT2A inverse agonist

general.notes: 34 mg daily; for PD psychosis

parkinson-s-disease-psychosis-hallucinat.notes: 34 mg once daily; takes 4-6 weeks for effect; no titration needed

fda-approved-for-tourette-syndrome-reser.indication: FDA-approved for Tourette syndrome; reserved for refractory cases due to QTc risk
fda-approved-for-tourette-syndrome-reser.notes: Start 0.5 mg qHS; increase by 0.5-1 mg q1wk; target 2-4 mg/day; max 10 mg/day (0.2 mg/kg/day in children); CYP2D6 genotyping recommended at doses >4 mg

ongoing: ECG at baseline, each dose increase, and q6mo

when-pimozide-is-causative-agent-slow-ta.indication: When pimozide is causative agent; slow taper required
when-pimozide-is-causative-agent-slow-ta.notes: Reduce by 25% q1-2 weeks; do not discontinue abruptly; coordinate with psychiatry for alternative

contraindications: Active psychosis without alternative (coordinate with psychiatry)

cortical-myoclonus-may-be-effective-for-.indication: Cortical myoclonus -- may be effective for CJD myoclonus; not FDA-approved in US but available internationally
cortical-myoclonus-may-be-effective-for-.notes: Start 2400 mg PO TID; may increase to 4800 mg TID; max 24 g/day

eds-and-cataplexy-in-narcolepsy-histamin.indication: EDS and cataplexy in narcolepsy; histamine-3 receptor antagonist/inverse agonist
eds-and-cataplexy-in-narcolepsy-histamin.notes: Start 8.9 mg once daily upon awakening; titrate weekly: 8.9 mg to 17.8 mg to 35.6 mg; max 35.6 mg/day

general.notes: If dexamethasone >20 mg/week AND concomitant temozolomide or immunosuppression: TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet 3x/week (Mon/Wed/Fri) OR atovaquone 1500 mg daily if sulfa allergic

ongoing: Risk of Pneumocystis with prolonged corticosteroids + additional immunosuppression

gbs-cidp-alternative-to-ivig.notes: 5-7 exchanges of 1 plasma volume each over 10-14 days

acute-lems-exacerbation-alternative-to-i.indication: Acute LEMS exacerbation; alternative to IVIg; LEMS crisis with respiratory compromise; pre-thymectomy optimization if concurrent thymoma
acute-lems-exacerbation-alternative-to-i.notes: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; exchange 1-1.5 plasma volumes per session every other day; albumin replacement preferred

chronic-lems-refractory-to-ivig-and-oral.indication: Chronic LEMS refractory to IVIg and oral immunotherapy
chronic-lems-refractory-to-ivig-and-oral.notes: Single volume exchange every 2-4 weeks; adjust frequency based on clinical response and antibody levels; albumin replacement

autoimmune-cerebellar-ataxia-refractory-.indication: Autoimmune cerebellar ataxia refractory to steroids/IVIG; Miller Fisher syndrome; paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (limited benefit once neuronal loss established)
autoimmune-cerebellar-ataxia-refractory-.notes: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; albumin replacement

refractory-susac-syndrome-not-responding.indication: Refractory Susac syndrome not responding to steroids + IVIG; acute deterioration; removal of circulating anti-endothelial cell antibodies and inflammatory mediators

doseOptions.orderSentence: Plasma exchange (plasmapheresis, PLEX) (CPT 36514) 5 exchanges over 10-14 days IV

refractory-susac-syndrome-not-responding.notes: 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; albumin replacement; 5-7 sessions over 10-14 days; extend to 10 sessions in severe cases

severe-inflammatory-plexopathy-refractor.indication: Severe inflammatory plexopathy refractory to steroids and IVIg; CIDP-like plexopathy
severe-inflammatory-plexopathy-refractor.notes: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange

steroid-refractory-or-severe-vision-loss.notes: 5-7 exchanges every other day; typical volume 1-1.5 plasma volumes

acute-severe-sps-or-status-spasticus-not.indication: Acute severe SPS or status spasticus not responding to benzodiazepines and IVIg; removes pathogenic antibodies
acute-severe-sps-or-status-spasticus-not.notes: 5 exchanges over 10-14 days (every other day); 1-1.5 plasma volume exchanges per session; albumin replacement (NOT FFP unless coagulopathy); central venous catheter required

first-line-immunotherapy-removes-pathoge.indication: First-line immunotherapy; removes pathogenic antibodies; preferred for cell-surface antibody syndromes
first-line-immunotherapy-removes-pathoge.notes: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; albumin replacement preferred

experimental-refractory-cases-patient-pr.indication: Experimental; refractory cases; patient preference to avoid surgery

doseOptions.orderSentence: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injection 2-3 mL PRP Local injection

experimental-refractory-cases-patient-pr.notes: Single injection under ultrasound; emerging evidence

thrombocytopenia-with-active-bleeding-or.indication: Thrombocytopenia with active bleeding or pre-procedure

doseOptions.orderSentence: Platelet transfusion Dose per protocol IV

thrombocytopenia-with-active-bleeding-or.notes: 1 unit apheresis platelets; target >50K for procedures, >10K if no bleeding

constipation-common-with-reduced-mobilit.indication: Constipation (common with reduced mobility and anticholinergics)
constipation-common-with-reduced-mobilit.notes: 17 g in 8 oz liquid daily; may increase to BID

constipation.notes: 17 g (1 capful) in 8 oz liquid daily; may increase to BID

constipation-refractory-to-docusate-and-.indication: Constipation refractory to docusate and senna
constipation-refractory-to-docusate-and-.notes: 17 g PO daily dissolved in 8 oz water

constipation-immobility-related-common-i.indication: Constipation (immobility-related, common in IBM due to reduced activity)
constipation-immobility-related-common-i.notes: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz liquid PO daily; adjust frequency based on response

general.notes: 17 g daily in water

constipation-refractory-to-docusate-senn.notes: 17 g PO daily in 8 oz water; may increase to BID

constipation-from-neurogenic-bowel-or-im.indication: Constipation from neurogenic bowel or immobility
constipation-from-neurogenic-bowel-or-im.notes: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz water daily

constipation-from-autonomic-dysfunction-.indication: Constipation from autonomic dysfunction in LEMS
constipation-from-autonomic-dysfunction-.notes: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz liquid once daily; adjust frequency to bowel response

constipation-neurogenic-bowel-dysfunctio.notes: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz water daily; titrate frequency to effect; target 1 soft stool daily

chronic-constipation-from-neurogenic-bow.indication: Chronic constipation from neurogenic bowel; osmotic laxative
chronic-constipation-from-neurogenic-bow.notes: 17 g dissolved in 8 oz water PO daily; adjust frequency based on response

general.notes: Titration over 14 days to 20 mg daily

salvage-therapy-for-refractory-aspergill.notes: Loading: 300 mg PO BID on day 1; Maintenance: 300 mg PO daily; delayed-release tablets preferred (consistent absorption)

hypokalemia-correction-common-in-alcohol.notes: Replace per level: K 3.0-3.5: 40 mEq PO; K <3.0: 20-40 mEq IV over 1-2 hours; check Mg (must replete Mg for K to correct)

amphotericin-b-causes-renal-potassium-wa.notes: Replace per institutional protocol; target K >3.5 mEq/L; oral preferred if tolerated; IV replacement for K <3.0 or symptomatic

ongoing: Potassium levels twice daily during induction

prevent-hypokalemia-during-b12-replaceme.notes: 20-40 mEq PO daily; monitor potassium q12-24h during first 48 hours of B12 replacement; supplement if K <3.5 mEq/L

ongoing: Potassium levels q12-24h during initial treatment

general.notes: Omeprazole 20 mg daily or pantoprazole 40 mg daily while on dexamethasone

general.notes: Start 0.125 mg TID; titrate weekly to 0.5-1.5 mg TID; max 4.5 mg/day

adjunct-to-levodopa-monotherapy-in-early.indication: Adjunct to levodopa; monotherapy in early PD; tremor
adjunct-to-levodopa-monotherapy-in-early.notes: Start 0.125 mg TID; titrate by 0.125-0.25 mg TID q5-7 days; max 1.5 mg TID

general.notes: Start 0.375 mg daily; titrate weekly; max 4.5 mg/day

contraindications: pregnancy (Category B but avoid during treatment)

ptsd-related-nightmares-and-sleep-disrup.indication: PTSD-related nightmares and sleep disruption (common in PNES patients with trauma history)
ptsd-related-nightmares-and-sleep-disrup.notes: Start 1 mg PO qHS; titrate by 1-2 mg q1wk; max 15 mg qHS; monitor for first-dose hypotension (give first dose at bedtime)

general.notes: 60-80 mg PO daily × 7 days (equivalent alternative)

prednisone.name: Prednisone

doseOptions.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone 1000 mg IV daily x3-5 days
Prednisone 1250 mg PO daily x3-5 days

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone 60 mg PO daily x7 days then taper
Prednisone 50 mg PO daily x10 days

bells-palsy.titration: 7-10 day course; can taper over 5 days or stop

cidp-vasculitic-neuropathy-sarcoid-neuro.notes: 1 mg/kg/day (max 80 mg) x 4-6 weeks; taper over 3-6 months

transition-from-iv-steroids-maintenance-.indication: Transition from IV steroids; maintenance corticosteroid therapy for pNBD
transition-from-iv-steroids-maintenance-.notes: Start 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) after IV pulse; taper by 10 mg every 2 weeks to 20 mg, then by 5 mg every 2-4 weeks; goal <10 mg daily by 6 months; taper over 6-12+ months

transition-from-iv-steroids-maintenance-.indication: Transition from IV steroids; maintenance corticosteroid therapy
transition-from-iv-steroids-maintenance-.notes: Start 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) after IV pulse; taper by 10 mg every 2 weeks to 20 mg, then by 5 mg every 2-4 weeks to lowest effective dose (goal 5-10 mg daily or off); total taper over 6-12 months

outpatient-management-of-refractory-sih-.indication: Outpatient management of refractory SIH; meningeal inflammation
outpatient-management-of-refractory-sih-.notes: 60 mg PO daily x 5 days, then taper by 10 mg every 3-5 days over 3-4 weeks

hospital-setting-with-crisis-protection-.notes: 60-80 mg or 1 mg/kg daily; only start high-dose after IVIg/PLEX coverage in hospital or if admitted for monitoring

chronic-mg-on-stable-steroids.notes: Once stable on target dose x 2-4 weeks, begin slow taper: reduce by 10 mg q2-4 weeks until 20 mg, then by 5 mg q2-4 weeks until 10 mg, then by 2.5 mg q month; may need minimum maintenance dose indefinitely

oral-corticosteroid-taper-following-iv-m.indication: Oral corticosteroid taper following IV methylprednisolone pulse; bridge to steroid-sparing maintenance therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (oral, following IV pulse) 1 mg/kg daily PO
Prednisone (oral, following IV pulse) 0.75 mg/kg daily PO
Prednisone (oral, following IV pulse) 0.5 mg/kg daily PO

oral-corticosteroid-taper-following-iv-m.notes: Start 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 80 mg) after IV pulse; taper by 10 mg every 2 weeks to 20 mg/day; then taper by 5 mg every 2 weeks to 10 mg/day; then 2.5 mg every 2-4 weeks; target off steroids or lowest effective dose by 6-12 months

time-limited-trial-12-weeks-only-if-diag.indication: Time-limited trial (12 weeks) ONLY if diagnosis uncertain and polymyositis remains in differential; most IBM patients do NOT respond; steroid myopathy may worsen weakness
time-limited-trial-12-weeks-only-if-diag.notes: Start 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) as single morning dose; assess strength and CK at 4, 8, 12 weeks; taper and discontinue if no objective improvement by 12 weeks; steroid myopathy can WORSEN IBM weakness

transition-from-iv-dexamethasone-prolong.indication: Transition from IV dexamethasone; prolonged steroid course for subarachnoid NCC; maintenance anti-inflammatory therapy during outpatient antiparasitic treatment
transition-from-iv-dexamethasone-prolong.notes: 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 60 mg) then taper over 2-4 weeks for parenchymal NCC; for subarachnoid/racemose NCC: prolonged taper over months (years for chronic arachnoiditis)

cidp-vasculitic-neuropathy.notes: 1 mg/kg/day (max 80 mg) Ãƒâ€” 4-6 weeks; taper over 3-6 months

gca-without-visual-symptoms-after-iv-pul.indication: GCA without visual symptoms; after IV pulse for vision-threatening GCA
gca-without-visual-symptoms-after-iv-pul.notes: 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 60 mg); take in morning with food; maintain initial dose 2-4 weeks until symptoms resolve and ESR/CRP normalize

after-2-4-weeks-at-initial-dose-with-sym.indication: After 2-4 weeks at initial dose with symptom resolution

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (taper phase 1: 40 mg → 20 mg) 40 mg PO

after-2-4-weeks-at-initial-dose-with-sym.notes: Reduce by 5-10 mg every 2 weeks from 40 mg to 20 mg; monitor symptoms and ESR/CRP at each step

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (taper phase 2: 20 mg → 10 mg) 20 mg PO

continued-improvement-normal-inflammator.notes: Reduce by 2.5 mg every 2-4 weeks from 20 mg to 10 mg; slower taper reduces relapse risk

near-remission-on-steroid-sparing-agent-.indication: Near-remission; on steroid-sparing agent if available

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (taper phase 3: 10 mg → off) 10 mg PO

near-remission-on-steroid-sparing-agent-.notes: Reduce by 1 mg every month from 10 mg to off; total steroid duration typically 12-24 months; some patients require low-dose indefinitely

adjunctive-immunosuppression-short-term-.indication: Adjunctive immunosuppression; short-term during acute flares; bridge while waiting for IVIg/rituximab effect; less effective as monotherapy for SPS

acute-radiculopathy-with-moderate-severe.notes: 60 mg daily x 5 days then taper; OR Medrol dose pack

acute-inflammatory-plexopathy-parsonage-.notes: 60 mg PO daily x 5-7 days then taper over 2-4 weeks; total course 4-6 weeks for inflammatory etiology

short-course-for-acute-facial-nerve-pals.indication: Short course for acute facial nerve palsy to reduce inflammation and improve recovery; evidence extrapolated from Bell's palsy data; NOT standard of care for Lyme facial palsy and NOT recommended by most experts; discuss with specialist

Adrenal suppression with prolonged use - taper required

Cataracts and glaucoma with prolonged use

patientCounseling: Take with food to reduce stomach upset
Do not stop abruptly if on >7-10 days - must taper
May cause insomnia - take in morning
Monitor blood sugar if diabetic
Report signs of infection, GI bleeding, or mood changes
Consider calcium/vitamin D supplementation if prolonged use

following-iv-methylprednisolone-per-ontt.indication: Following IV methylprednisolone per ONTT protocol

establish-paco2-baseline-must-be-35-45-m.indication: Establish PaCO2 baseline; must be 35-45 mmHg before starting apnea test
establish-paco2-baseline-must-be-35-45-m.notes: Draw ABG after pre-oxygenation; adjust ventilator to normalize PaCO2 if needed; if baseline PaCO2 chronically elevated (e.g., COPD), target must be ≥20 mmHg above chronic baseline AND ≥60 mmHg

contraindications: If PaCO2 cannot be normalized to 35-45 (chronic hypercarbia), document chronic baseline and adjust targets accordingly

ongoing: if chronically elevated CO2, document baseline

step-3-disconnect-ventilator-and-apply-o.name: Step 3: Disconnect ventilator and apply O2

apnea-test-initiation-remove-external-re.indication: Apnea test initiation; remove external respiratory drive; observe for spontaneous respiratory effort

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Step 3: Disconnect ventilator and apply O2** 6-10 L/min O2 Intratracheal

apnea-test-initiation-remove-external-re.notes: Disconnect from ventilator; immediately place O2 cannula into trachea (or T-piece with CPAP at 5-10 cmH2O) delivering 6-10 L/min O2 at carina level; ensures oxygenation without ventilation

contraindications: Severe ARDS with FiO2 >0.7 and PEEP >10 (may desaturate rapidly — consider ancillary test instead)

ongoing: direct observation for ANY respiratory movement (chest, abdomen)

confirm-paco2-rise-meets-threshold-for-v.indication: Confirm PaCO2 rise meets threshold for valid test
confirm-paco2-rise-meets-threshold-for-v.notes: Draw ABG at 8-10 minutes of apnea (or sooner if SpO2 <85%); POSITIVE (absent respiratory drive): PaCO2 ≥60 mmHg AND rise ≥20 mmHg above baseline

contraindications: If PaCO2 target not reached and test aborted for desaturation, test is INCONCLUSIVE — need ancillary test

ongoing: PaCO2 ≥60 mmHg AND ≥20 above baseline = POSITIVE (brain death)
if target not met → repeat or ancillary test

general.notes: **MG crisis precipitants (AVOID):** Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, tobramycin), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin — less risky but still caution), macrolides (azithromycin, erythromycin), beta-blockers, magnesium (IV), neuromuscular blockers, D-penicillamine, interferon-alpha, checkpoint inhibitors (nivolumab, pembrolizumab); **Full list in Appendix**

ongoing: Many medications can worsen neuromuscular transmission

urinary-hesitancy-and-retention-from-neu.indication: Urinary hesitancy and retention from neurogenic bladder; facilitates bladder emptying
urinary-hesitancy-and-retention-from-neu.notes: 0.4 mg PO daily 30 minutes after same meal; max 0.8 mg daily

contraindications: Severe orthostatic hypotension (may worsen OH), hypersensitivity

ongoing: Orthostatic BP (may exacerbate OH — use cautiously in MSA), dizziness, retrograde ejaculation

general.notes: 50 mg BID; titrate by 50 mg q3 days; max 500 mg/day

refractory-pain-mu-opioid-agonist-with-n.indication: Refractory pain; mu-opioid agonist with norepinephrine reuptake inhibition
refractory-pain-mu-opioid-agonist-with-n.notes: Start 50 mg BID; titrate by 50 mg BID q3d; max 500 mg/day

moderate-severe-neuropathic-pain.notes: Start 50 mg BID; increase by 50 mg BID every 3 days; max 250 mg BID

targeted-iv-antibiotic-therapy.name: Targeted IV antibiotic therapy (based on culture results)

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Targeted IV antibiotic therapy (based on culture results)** 2g IV

general.notes: **Tailor to organism and sensitivities; typical regimens:** — **MSSA:** Nafcillin 2g IV q4h OR cefazolin 2g IV q8h (preferred for tolerability); duration 6-8 weeks; — **MRSA:** Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h (trough 15-20) for 6-8 weeks; alternatives: daptomycin 6-8 mg/kg IV daily (avoid if pneumonia), linezolid 600 mg IV/PO q12h (monitor for toxicity if >2 weeks); — **Streptococci:** Penicillin G 4 million units IV q4h or ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h x 6 weeks; — **Enterococcus:** Ampicillin 2g IV q4h (if susceptible) ± gentamicin synergy; vancomycin if ampicillin-resistant; — **Gram-negatives:** Ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h or cefepime 2g IV q8h or ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV q8h x 6 weeks depending on sensitivities; — **Pseudomonas:** Cefepime 2g IV q8h or meropenem 2g IV q8h x 6 weeks

ongoing: IV antibiotics are standard for SEA/osteomyelitis
de-escalate from empiric coverage once cultures return
oral transition data emerging (OVIVA trial) but traditionally 6-8 weeks IV

all-comatose-cardiac-arrest-survivors-gc.indication: ALL comatose cardiac arrest survivors (GCS motor <6 after ROSC). TTM2 trial: no difference between 33C vs 36C; both superior to fever. AHA/ILCOR 2020: target 32-36C for at least 24h

doseOptions.orderSentence: Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) — cooling to 32-36C 32-36C external/IV

all-comatose-cardiac-arrest-survivors-gc.notes: Initiate cooling ASAP post-ROSC; use surface (Arctic Sun) or intravascular (Thermogard) cooling; target temperature within 4h; maintain for at least 24h; rewarm at 0.25C/h (avoid >0.5C/h); prevent fever (<37.7C) for at least 72h after ROSC

ongoing: Core temperature (esophageal or bladder probe) continuously
electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca, Phos) q4-6h during cooling
skin checks q4h for surface cooling

relapsed-refractory-pcnsl-after-hd-mtx-f.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL after HD-MTX failure; oral alkylating agent with CNS penetration
relapsed-refractory-pcnsl-after-hd-mtx-f.notes: 150-200 mg/m2 PO days 1-5 of 28-day cycle; take on empty stomach 1h before bed; antiemetic pre-medication

recurrent-atypical-or-anaplastic-meningi.indication: Recurrent atypical or anaplastic meningioma (WHO grade II/III) refractory to surgery and radiation; limited evidence; consider when no clinical trial available
recurrent-atypical-or-anaplastic-meningi.notes: 150-200 mg/m2 PO days 1-5 of 28-day cycle; take on empty stomach 1h before bedtime; antiemetic pre-medication

ongoing: CBC Day 1 and Day 22 of each cycle
watch for lymphopenia and opportunistic infections

standard-adjuvant-chemotherapy-following.indication: Standard adjuvant chemotherapy following concurrent chemoradiation; 6 cycles of dose-dense temozolomide

doseOptions.orderSentence: Temozolomide - Adjuvant (Stupp Protocol Phase 2) 150 mg/m2 PO

standard-adjuvant-chemotherapy-following.notes: Cycle 1: 150 mg/m2 PO days 1-5 of 28-day cycle; if tolerated (ANC >1500, platelets >100K), increase to 200 mg/m2 for cycles 2-6; take on empty stomach 1h before bedtime; antiemetic pre-medication; 6 cycles total

ongoing: CBC Day 1 and Day 22 of each cycle
MGMT methylation-positive patients have better response (median OS ~21 months vs. ~14 months)
hold if ANC <1000 or platelets <50K until recovery
reduce dose by 50 mg/m2 for Grade 3-4 toxicity

elderly-patients-70-or-poor-functional-s.indication: Elderly patients (>70) or poor functional status (KPS 30-60) who cannot tolerate radiation; consider if MGMT methylated (better response); Wick et al. Lancet Oncol 2012 (NOA-08)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Temozolomide alone (elderly/poor KPS without RT) 150 mg/m2 PO

elderly-patients-70-or-poor-functional-s.notes: Standard 5/28 day dosing (as per adjuvant protocol); MGMT methylation status guides decision: methylated = temozolomide preferred; unmethylated = consider RT alone or best supportive care

temozolomide-concurrent-with-rt.name: Temozolomide - Concurrent with RT (Stupp Protocol Phase 1)

standard-of-care-for-newly-diagnosed-gbm.indication: Standard of care for newly diagnosed GBM; concurrent with focal radiation (60 Gy in 30 fractions); Stupp et al. NEJM 2005 demonstrated OS benefit (14.6 vs. 12.1 months)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Temozolomide - Concurrent with RT (Stupp Protocol Phase 1) 75 mg/m2 PO

standard-of-care-for-newly-diagnosed-gbm.notes: 75 mg/m2 PO daily throughout radiation (42 consecutive days including weekends/holidays); take on empty stomach 1 hour before bedtime; antiemetic 30-60 min before (ondansetron 8 mg); PJP prophylaxis (TMP-SMX) mandatory

contraindications: known hypersensitivity to temozolomide or dacarbazine

ongoing: if ANC <1000 or platelets <50K, hold temozolomide until recovery

recurrent-gbm-with-prior-temozolomide-re.indication: Recurrent GBM with prior temozolomide response; dose-dense or metronomic schedule; consider if long interval since initial treatment
recurrent-gbm-with-prior-temozolomide-re.notes: Dose-dense: 75-150 mg/m2 PO daily x 21 days of 28-day cycle; metronomic: 50 mg/m2 PO daily continuous; take on empty stomach 1h before bed

ongoing: CBC weekly for first 2 cycles, then q2 weeks

general.notes: Targeted temperature: 36-37C; cooling blankets; acetaminophen 1g IV/PO q6h PRN

alternative-thrombolytic-for-acute-poste.indication: Alternative thrombolytic for acute posterior circulation stroke; single bolus dosing
alternative-thrombolytic-for-acute-poste.notes: 0.25 mg/kg IV bolus (max 25 mg); single dose; emerging evidence for posterior circulation

acute-ischemic-stroke-with-lvo-from-diss.indication: Acute ischemic stroke with LVO from dissection; preferred if thrombectomy planned

general.notes: 0.25 mg/kg IV single bolus (max 25 mg); preferred if LVO planned for thrombectomy

nrti-backbone-taf-with-moderate-cpe-pref.indication: NRTI backbone; TAF with moderate CPE; preferred over TDF for renal/bone safety

ECG at baseline and q2-4 weeks during taper
ECG at baseline, after each dose increase
for hemiplegic migraine when triptans contraindicated

general.notes: Meclizine 25 mg q8h OR dimenhydrinate 50 mg q6h OR diazepam 5 mg BID x 1-3 days ONLY; taper off as soon as tolerated

ongoing: INR daily until stable, then weekly, then monthly

serum zinc level q3-6 months (target 125-150 mcg/dL)
